review_title: Am I supposed to root for Snake Eyes?

review_detailed_main:
Characters try hard to be cool but end up being boring and weak.

Plot is all over the place, Snake Eyes is the weakest character in the movie but somehow he is the only one that triumphs.

Action is short and choppy, a massive fight is about to begin and then it last 3 seconds and cuts to some other scene and after that scene is over we go back to the fight scene which is also over, and that happens all the time.

When you have an actor like Iko and don't use him in a movie like this you are wasting potentialy excellent fight scenes.

Don't waste time and money on this DOA movie.

review_title: Mediocre and badly written - one great film saving performance....
review_detailed_main:
So this is now essentially the third attempt to bring GI Joe to the big screen. Lorenzo Di Bonaventura returns at the helm and proves once again - he does not really care... Honestly - how this film actually came to be is beyond me - a group of professional people working in the industry collectively decided that firstly : this film should be made - then that Evan Spiliotopoulos (who has hardly written a single great film to date) should write the damn thing - then add a director, Schwentke (who has a track record of terrible blockbuster films) - and let's top it off with TV travel host/Rom-com break out - Henry Golding to play Snake eyes himself. Shocking....

SO - It definitely is not the Snake eyes that people know and love. He does bad things in this film and unfortunately, Henry isn't a skilled enough actor to make you like him. I disagree that it was purely in the writing - a great actor can make you care for the most despicable characters but Golding proves here he should stick to Rom-coms...and his own accent. His physical skills and acting feel forced and awkward and in my opinion needs a lot of work if I would ever buy him as a legitimate action star. He does have some charisma and good looks though.

It seems like the majority of the articles and social media agree that the film's saving grace is Andrew Koji's Storm Shadow. He adds nuance and depth to Tommy (even though he is dealt the rough hand with having to deliver the majority of the exposition) He commands the screen whenever he is on and delivers us the most layered Storm Shadow in almost any medium to date - just too bad he is let down by an awful script. Koji steals the show with his performance and to top it off you can tell he knows how to move - his action moments were by far the most fun to watch - although he was let down by a terrible filming style there too. I definitely want to see more of Koji. Jin Sakai for Ghost of Tsushima!

The rest of the cast are great in their limited roles - Samara, Ursula, Iko and Peter Mensah - all do great. They are well cast but under utilised. Hollywood SERIOUSLY needs to stop thinking they know best with martial arts action sequences - Iko and Kenji Tanigaki's team is absolutely wasted here.

There was a lot of potential with a GI Joe reboot. There was some potential for a good Snake eyes film - but these people clearly are not the right people to do it. Paramount needs to learn. You would have thought Lorenzo etc would have learnt something since the last films 10 years ago - but clearly not. They have not only destroyed many people's favourite character - they have simple made a bad film and wasted a lot of money and talent....

5.5/10.

review_title: Horribly filmed action ruined this movie
review_detailed_main:
I'm a big fan of Yakuza films, so when I saw the trailer for "Snake Eyes," I was ecstatic - a gritty, grounded origin of one of G. I. Joe's most beloved characters, in the form of a Japanese mobster movie, seemed too good to be true. And lo and behold, it was! "Snake Eyes" seems to suffer from an identity crisis; there is not enough gangster politics to be a successful gangster movie - there is not enough character development to be a satisfying drama - and perhaps the worst offense: there is not enough well-filmed action for this to be a great action film.

Let's jump right into why "Snake Eyes" isn't a good film - the action. When you hire master choreographers to create beautiful action sequences, why would you then destroy them by choosing to film your action with close-up, handheld, shaky cam? This stylistic decision is infuriating and unforgivable. There was only one sequence in this movie that was well shot; other than that, literally every other single action scene was made incomprehensible due to the filmmaking.

There were so many set pieces that could've been memorable and exciting if only the cameraman would've put the camera on a tripod, prepared a wide shot, and stepped away. You have scenes of small armies engaged in katana-on-katana action, and you won't be able to see any of it because the cameraman is standing two feet away and shaking the camera like it owes him money. This filmmaking decision literally ruined the action in this film, and as a consequence, ruined the film itself - because when the action in your action movie sucks, your movie sucks.

That said, perhaps the storyline and the engaging characters can add some sort of entertainment value? You'd be half right. The story itself is pretty interesting, if not very engaging. There's enough to keep you slightly invested in what's happening and why, but again, everything is framed around terribly filmed action sequences that damper the fun. The acting was serviceable, but nothing too breathtaking. Henry Golding as Snake Eyes had a certain tenacity about him that was fun to watch, but the script seemed to try a little too hard to make him "cool." Samara Weaving was gorgeous, as always, and pretty good here - however, she barely has any screen time, and isn't introduced until about half way through the film. That said, she is a show stealer when she's on screen.

"Snake Eyes" did have some cool cinematography to bask at - if you enjoy Asian cinema, you'll certainly enjoy the look of the film. That said, if you enjoy good action, you're going to despise this movie. I'd recommend only checking this out if you're a big G. I. Joe fan - if you're not? There's a million other Yakuza action films at your disposal; don't waste your time with this.
Andrew. Koji steals the attention with his emotional expression, too bad his lines were not so good. I think he should be snake eyes.

Just another reboot/remake/rehash/whatever of an old intellectual property that tries to capitalize on the diversity of it's actors, much like the Mortal Kombat reboot released earlier this year.

We get nothing about the origins of G. I. Joe, Snake Eyes' induction into the team, or Cobra's origins. Just a generic, "gritty", MCU-styled action film that doesn't respect the source material and features characters who only look good and are charisma vacuums.

The Stephen Sommers films (which were terrible) did a better job depicting Snake Eyes as the lethal, stealthy, and charismatic mute he truly is.

review_title: Except for a pair of dice and a random "G.I. Joe" label, this is an assembly of every cliche, sloppily presented.
review_detailed_main:
Three seasoned screenwriters came up with this sloppy and convoluted mess of a story? The two hours felt dragged out with the most cliched action/martial-arts forgettable story, that was riddled with plot and technical issues. I can't remember the last time I saw such a predictable film.

Don't get me started on the cheesy dialogue and lame attempts at humor. Director Robert Schwentke also failed to give much cohesion to the all-over-the-place script with his annoying shaky-cam and sword-cut editing, as well as his (mostly) migraine-inducing action scenes. He tried too hard - and failed to make this a blockbuster, instead of the B grade action film it was.

Henry Golding as Snake-Eyes lacked the action-hero presence and was about as convincing as Clint Eastwood as a stand-up comedian. The rest of the casting and performances were decent, but the only redeeming quality of this film was the amazing production sets and costumes. It's a generous 6/10 from me.

I don't know much about G. I. Joe, but I've watched the movies. I've always wanted to see a solo Snake Eyes film because I was intrigued by the character. This movie does a pretty good job showing us the origin story of this character and his history. It's not perfect but it's pretty decent in my opinion.

review_title: A fantastic cast completely wasted on a stupid story
review_detailed_main:
First of all, this has *nothing* to do with G. I. Joe, as it is a medieval story about two Japanese clans and the protagonist is caught somewhat in between. Yes, it happens today, but 90% of all fights are using swords and the prize of the war is a magical stone. It's like someone took an existing Japanese samurai and ninjas script, added an extraneous character and made him the protagonist, then plastered on a Joe/Cobra connection and brought it into the present. And the way they added this stuff is like fixing a broken mirror with industrial sticky tape on the visible side.

And what a cast this had: Andrew Koji from Warrior (I still crave for a new season), Iko Uwais from Raid, Peter Mensah from Spartacus, Takehiro Hira (who in my mind did the best job in the film, even if he was the villain and had a really dumb role), Samara Weaving from Guns Akimbo. Not to mention Eri Ishida, who did more in a few scenes than "Snake Eyes" in the entire film. They did nothing with all of this. The fights were fractured and made little sense, focused on form and ignoring substance. Two people fighting 50 and succeeding because they all used swords and the heroes had unlimited stamina, the usual running (slowly and awkwardly) from bullets scene, people running in the sword range to fire a gun, ugh! It was incredibly ugly. Even the motorcycle and car scenes were ridiculously bad. A team of 5 snipers could have finished *everybody* without loses.

Worst of all, it's called G. I. Joe Origins and it features a character who has never heard of the Joes in a time when both Cobra and Joes have been established for a long time. There is no origin story at all! There is no story, really!

Bottom line: this film is something that whole teams of people should be fired because of. A 100 million dollar film that manages to waste every resource it bought. Avoid it like it's the plague.

review_title: Forget everything you know about Snake Eyes.
review_detailed_main:
So, I've been a fan of G. I. Joe since I got my first Joes in 1983. Now when this movie was first talked about I said it would suck and be absolute trash. I went to see it anyway and I went with an open mind. Now there was a few times I muttered some curse words under my breathed but I still keep an open mind. I really liked this movie.

To enjoy it you must forget everything you know about G. I. Joe. There was a good storyline, great action scenes, and the characters, especially Storm Shadow, were well written. It was a great movie. There is a few spots that take away which I'm not going to mention, but even with those it doesn't kill the movie. The best thing is it definitely leads into a new Joe Universe.

Give this movie a chance, just go into it with an open mind.

review_title: Never mind the plot holes, enjoy the action
review_detailed_main: Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins: A good adventure story, MMA, sword fighting, gunplay, Ninjas, international conspiracies, motorbike chases and a lust for vengeance. Don't worry about plot holes and non sequiturs, let the action carry you along. A feel of Akira and Blade Runner in the production design helps. Directed by Robert Schwentke, written by Evan Spillotopoulos. 6/10.

review_title: Shoddy Film - Bad Casting - Disrespects Source Material
review_detailed_main:
Saw the movie last night and was not impressed with anything I saw. The makers of this film have either no idea of the origins of Snake-Eyes or they intentionally destroyed the character. Aside from the fact that Snake-Eyes was always a Gaijin (white guy) he was also honorable in all that he did. This version has him as a two-faced, lying, thief. The feeble redemption arc in the final act was too little - too late, and unbelievable. The casting choices also left me a bit confused. Golding was never a good choice for Snake-Eyes and as much as I love Samara Weaving, she was a horrible Scarlet. The actress who ineptly portrayed the Baroness was too young for the character and was not even close to being believable. Iko Uwais was great as usual but would have been a much better Storm Shadow or even Snake-Eyes! Andrew Koji did do a good job as Storm Shadow and his was the best performance in the whole film by far.

The story was subpar, even for a genre piece, and the script could have been written by a middle-schooler. The action was decently choreographed and wasn't too over the top. It seemed like it couldn't decide whether to be gritty or cartoonish in its approach to the action, which was a letdown. There are several continuity issues as well; a brawler raised on the street with no formal training can automatically hold his own against highly trained ninjas (can you say Rey Palpatine?) or a girl who had been a devoted part of the clan for over a decade breaking sacred rules to save someone she just met?

All in all, this movie sucked!

review_title: Throwing things at a wall bad

review_detailed_main:
We don't often get good budget ninja movies these days. I finally got around to watching Snake Eyes today, and actually enjoyed it.

It's definitely a movie not to be taken seriously. If you are a martial arts Action buff like I am - give Snake Eyes a chance.

The Action/martial arts scenes are more than adequate.

I was genuinely so excited to see this, the trailers looked amazing. High octane for sure, but the total absence of a plot made this really tough to engage with.

If you like random fight scenes, you'll probably enjoy this, they move from one to another, to another, but at times you'll find yourself wanting to check your phone for a distraction. It was as if nobody bothered to read through a first draft of the screenplay, and just thought, it'll do.

How on Earth could such a movie be boring, but that's the story I'm afraid. The best element here for me was Andrew Koji.

I was glad to see the credits roll, and walked out of the cinema, wondering what on Earth I had just sat through.

review_title: Don't have high expectations on the story. Everything else is good.
review_detailed_main:
Henry Golding did a good job. Andrew Koji acted well and has a believable Japanese accent (he has a British accent in real life). This movie is 70 to 89% fighting. The story is not so believable as there is not much character development. Fighting is not as good Bruce Lee's Warrior where Andrew Koji played the main character. Warrior has the best fight scenes that Hollywood has produced. And the story is great too. Don't expect that standard in this movie.

Watch it to see Henry Golding and Andrew Koji fight. Don't take the story too seriously and you will enjoy it.

review_title: Awesome Action Film & An Excellent Origin Story
review_detailed_main:
I grew up on G. I. Joe action figures & the cartoon & i remember Snake Eyes being a fan favourite & now we have his own movie & its Awesome!!!

Ignore bad reviews.

Snake Eyes is the best G. I. Joe movie yet.

Henry Golding plays Snake Eyes & he's excellent in the role & is a very good actor that acts with his eyes alot & i love that. This story starts from the very beginning with when "Snake Eyes" was just a young boy that witnessed his father's murder that sends him into the dangerous underworld of Japan as he works his way through the Criminal underworld driven by rage. Snake Eyes eventually joins an ancient Japanese clan called the Arashikage after saving the life of their heir, Storm Shadow (played Brilliantly by Andrew Koji) but things get messy & Snake Eyes becomes conflicted with who his loyalty lies with.

I loved all the Ninja mythology & beautiful Japanese setting & the glowing Neon drenched streets & tons of adrenaline-fulled action set-pieces. The fight scenes are Awesome & the look of the film is stunning.

Snake Eyes has an old school 90's action movie feel to it that i dug because i grew up during those times & was obsessed with action films. If this came out back then in the 90's it would've probably starred Brandon Lee or Van Damme as Snake Eyes.

Snake Eyes is a great movie & a grest origin story of a beloved fan favourite.

Simply AWESOME.

review_title: Atrocious editing ruined the action sequences. The locations are top notch though.
review_detailed_main:
I saw this mainly cos of Iko Uwais n got terribly disappointed cos his footage is less n he doesnt get to kick ass.

Then i thot lets just enjoy the action but then again none of the fight scenes are noteworthy.

Recently i saw Lee's Fist of Fury n i loved the Japanese garden. This movie too has some some beautiful gardens, lakes, hill tops houses, etc.

The editing ruined everything.

Cos of the shaky cam n fast cut editing, one cannot make out what is going on during the fight scenes.

The character of Snake Eyes is more spiteful n the character of Shadow Storm more sympathetic.

How conveniently the clan n the Major Scarlett work together with Baroness, a Cobra member.

Also how easily Snake Eyes forgives his dad's murderer n after that fight alongside Baroness inspite of knowing that Cobra gang gave the orders to eliminate his dad.

I miss those old ninja movies man.

The movie has a average plot, but the Fights and Action scene were well choreographed, I like the whole Japanese Aesthetics. Also this movie gives a good backstory for Storm Shadow and Snake Eyes. The Character development of Snake Eyes was good. Overall I loved the movie. Hopefully we get a Sequel.

review_title: Don't let those negative reviews to fool you.
review_detailed_main: I don't understand why some people talking as like this movie has nothing for audience..!? They are giving it 1 or 2 star..!! Really? At least be reasonable. I get it, it's not a kids movie nor a fully dark adult movie. But what's wrong with that? Those who didn't see it, Give it a chance and it's a fun movie. Fun is enough for me. Don't listen to those toxic fan base..

review_title: More of what is becoming the norm.
review_detailed_main: Great visuals ruined by terrible writing. Hollywood is a big place, where are all the good writers at? And why do people keep agreeing to go along with a film after reading a terrible screenplay? People need to start speaking up before the film is complete about the writing.

Trust me take a nap.

At one point snake eyes goes on a magical trip in the forest to find the light. I took a magical trip to the bathroom. The add above the urinal was more interesting than this movie.

This movie sucked.

Pretty solid film for the G. I. Joe franchise. The story was well written and good action. The actors did a good job and I liked Snake Eye's tough choices he had to make, creating conflict. I kept thinking "if only the new Mortal Kombat was made this well". The thing lacking in this movie was blood. This film has setup more films to follow, and I'll go to the cinema to see them.

Why is it so hard for them to make a good GI Joe movie? Just stick with the source material for starters. Not only did they want to tell some other story, the movie came across like a low budget film. Acting was atrocious on top of it. I'll give 1 bonus point for Peter Mensah as the only quality actor.
The film about the origin of Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow of the GI Joe saga. As other films, this one also watchable with some decent action/thriller scenes.

review_title: If that's an origins film, then the origin is missing.
review_detailed_main:
Bad writing, which killed the character development and eventually the character itself.

Regarding the origins film, the actual origin's story is almost missing here! Why is snake eyes already so skilled? Since it's his origin story, then why don't you develop it?

Average film. Only thing worth it is Iko Uwais.

3,5 / 10.

review_title: A decent movie that could have been better
review_detailed_main:
Snake Eyes shows us why we both love and hate Hollywood adaptations. There is enough interesting aspects in the film to enjoy and one (or two) changes that make the audience go hmmm. In this case the thing that makes you h'mm will either lead you to hate it, or you will be I wish it wasn't in the film, but it's okay. I am in the damn I wish it wasn't in there but ... It is clear the script got a major rewrite at some point just before or during filming. We are never sure why Samara Weaving character, Scarlett, is in the film. Its clear that they had a plan at some point and she was supposed to be a "love interest" but it was either left on the cutting room floor or reworked.

I enjoyed Andrew Koji in his role as Tommy Arashikaga and as true foil to Henry Golding as Snake Eyes.

review_title: The film is not about anything.
review_detailed_main: How could you spoil the story about the cool ninja so much? Upset!

This is no MCU or DCU but it's as good or even better because it doesn't submit to please you - it leads! Best origin story yet; not just for martial arts but for any action adventure fantasy movie to date. Unpredictable turn of events and storyline; the anacondas got me jumping from my sit! It's my new favorite blockbuster movie this summer or better yet - for the whole of 2021!

I enjoyed Mortal Kombat but this one is up there - undeniably so much better & fun to watch. I am so glad I watched it on IMAX; fantastic VFX and SFX! Can't wait for this to be available in physical media or streaming so I can watch on a loop. Thank you G. I. JOE franchise!

review_title: Meehhh...still better than the other G.I Joes
review_detailed_main: I love Henry Golding and was so excited to see him in an action movie. He was handsome as ever, however, I was a little disappointed with the movie as a whole. The plot was a little weak, the first half of the movie is way too slow, and the fight scenes were a bit stale. I did appreciate that they took the movie more seriously than the other two G. I. Joe movies that were as cheesy as the cartoons. It was an entertaining movie, but there were so many missed opportunities. My review is similar to Black Widow in terms of the supporting character surpassing the titular character (BW took a back seat to Yelena as Snake Eyes took a backseat to Storm Shadow in their own movies). I actually think the actors that played Storm Shadow and Snake Eyes needed to swap roles. Henry Golding lacked the grit to play a hardened criminal doing what he needs to survive on the streets. He is too much of a pretty boy and too charming which worked exceptionally well with his previous roles in "Crazy Rich Asians" "A Simple Favor" and "Last Christmas", but didn't quite work for Snake Eyes. The actor playing Storm Shadow had a more stoic and menacing presence and better fighting skills. I would have probably bought Henry Golding as a shrewed, debonair, next in line clan leader treated somewhat like a prince where others do most of the fighting for him. He did well in "The Gentleman" as a ruthless, yet suave, villain but I'm not buying the stealth and lethal ninja with a newly developed conscious. I do think the movie was better than the rating it was given, but it was not a really solid movie.

First he's bad...then he's good, then no one knows if he's bad or good. But then he's...what a mess. Nothing about this movie makes sense..and you wonder why Snake Eyes doesn't talk. Or not suppose to.

Henry Goulding is terrible. Sort of a low rent Chow Yun Fat with less conviction to what he says. I mean...terrible. He's suppose to be orphan'd. The hell has he been doing since then? And when he is recruited by the Yakuza...we meet a low rent Ken Watanabe This whole movie feels low rent. Everything is paced...off. We know where feelings are suppose to land but it doesn't hit any of those spots. Don't get me started on Tommy/Storm Shadow. God is he obnoxious. Not once did I believe he had the chops to be the diabolical ninja. Instead...as stated by the dim developers of this flick...they wanted to make him more "millennial" yeah...that always works. Failed on all parts. And the arrogance to setup a sequel...oof...They just don't get it. But I'm sure that was contractually obligated.

Hot mess all around. Everyone says their lines like they know it's on paper. Dull and lifeless.

Very bad stuff.
Everything they could do wrong they did. It amazes me how can a producer see the finishing cut and be satisfied with this garbage.....full of plot holes no meaning to the entire movie.

review_title: slow, no depth, no Snake Eyes

review_detailed_main:
Ah now we have your average Joe.

I haven't watched any G. I. Joe movies, so I have no idea about Snake Eyes coming in. Because of this, I judge this movie only as an independent action, hoping it to be a great summer blockbuster. And I was disappointed.

Before the movie began, Henry Golding shared that there's gonna be a lot of action. That's true, as there were multiple sword fights. However, each fight was short and unsatisfying. The camera angles were bad, and I couldn't see the choreography clearly. Iko Uwais was in this movie, and he's a fantastic martial artist actor. However, he got little screen time. It's almost like they don't have the budget for long fight choreography.

The story was boring and not special. Snake Eyes was a bland and bad protagonist. I don't care much about his journey, and the ending for his character felt unjustified. It's not that Henry Golding's acting was bad, but the direction for his character made him like a side character.

The acting was okay across. Only Andrew Koji stood out as the Storm Shadow. He was pretty badass with the swords, especially his serious face. I think he stole the spotlight from Golding's Snake Eyes.

Overall, a mediocre story with unsatisfying action scenes. 5/10.

review_title: Subverted my expectations but not enough to be great
review_detailed_main: There are a lot of clever things that happen in this movie and good attention to detail along with some nice character work. The bad is the action scenes are pretty lame at times and whenever the 'Joes;' are introduced the film slows down to a exposition dump. It would have been better had it just focused on Snake eyes and a smaller scope story with introducing the larger themes in the sequel. Cause they didn't really even finish Snake Eye's backstory, this was more like a introduction when it could have had a nicely contained story with many sequel strings. The guy playing Snake Eyes and Akiko were wonderful to watch. Ever scene between them was great. The Trials were awesome. The car fight was entertaining. If they had just left some things out (Like the Joes) and kept the story self contained this would have been a great movie instead of a good one. Too much weighing it down!

You had one job. Good action, good fight scenes. You failed. As with many action movies, i could tell from the first fight it was going to be bad. And it was, throughout. You can't see anything. Constant close-ups and shaky cam. How is this still a thing? The action and fight scenes in G. I. Joe: Retaliation in 2013 were significantly better. I know this because i rewatched it the day before. Sm damn h.

On top of that, many of the scenes were dark. Lots of poor editing choices and quick-cuts. And worst of all, allow a fight scene to happen for more than 5 seconds. This seems to plague most hollywood movies. A fight will last 5 seconds before something interrupts, or one of them tackles the other and fall down a shaft. Can we just see a fight? Maybe 60 seconds? Or at least 30? Is that too much to ask?

YOU HAVE IKO UWAIS (from the raid redemption, a GOAT martial arts movie). How do you waste him? He can do anything! And you give him a two minute "fight scene" involving bowls of water??????? And another 30 seconds late in the movie??????? Unbelievable.

I also want to complain about another stupid hollywood trend. THIS MOVIE SHOULD BE RATED R. It's about ninjas fighting with swords, sais and throwing stars. There should be blood and stabbings, but we see none. Grow some balls plz. Or at least release the unrated cut simultaneously so we can choose. Sm damn h again

Other than that, the movie was mediocre overall. I was invested in the story most of the way, but then it delves into madness. I like the two lead actors, and i was invested in the characters, especially tommy. But it didn't amount to anything.

There were some really dumb moments and things that make no sense. Like using swords when you have guns. Or a guy with a magical stone that incinerates ppl but not using it to prevent his defeat. Also, in a movie entirely based in reality, a magical stone feels so out of place.

All in all, this wasn't a good movie, but i could have enjoyed it if the action was good (1 viewing, 7/28/2021)

The story is about how the character became Snake Eyes in the first place. It's a perfectly acceptable story. The stunts are excellent. The only complaint I have is the shaky camera during the fight scenes. It was a bit hard to follow sometimes. If you are triggered by ninja magic, then you have been warned.

No blood. Movie with swords and no blood. Swords clean in every fight.

You can explode a guy with magic rock but can't show no blood. Absurd.

review_title: Snake Eyes: GI Joe Origins Delves Deep Into The Mysterious Character And Provides Fans Just Enough Action Along The Way
review_detailed_main:
The latest film in the G. I. Joe cinematic universe has arrived with "Snake Eyes: GI Joe Origins". The film was originally planned to arrive in March of 2020 but faced delays due to cinematic closures during the Pandemic.

The film opens with a young boy being orphaned after a group of thugs kills his father. Years later the man is still obsessed with finding out who killed his father and earns a living in underground fighting known as Snake Eyes (Henry Golding)

His exploits get the attention of Kenta (Takehiro Hira); who hires him into his organization with a promise to help him find the man who killed his father.

Snake Eyes soon finds himself working on the docks where he smuggles guns into fish bound for Japan. Despite his misgivings working for criminals, he befriends a man named Tommy (Andrew Koji); who teases him about his demeaning work by calling him "Fish Boy".

When Kenta forces Snake Eyes to kill Tommy for being a spy; Snake Eyes refuses and the two make a daring escape to Japan. It is learned that Tommy is next in line to run his clan and that Kenta was banished years prior and plans revenge.

Despite mistrust from a trusted associate named Akiko (Hakura Abe); Snake Eyes begins his training in the Ninja Arts which should he survive will make him a valued part of the Clan which Tommy believes is correct thanks to his Blood Debt to Snake Eyes.

The film focuses on various aspects of training before branching into the larger story of divided loyalties and honors which results in a few battles and chases along the way.

While the film does space the action out; it does provide some great cinematography and the action is entertaining even if it lacks much tension.

The biggest issue is that the G. I. Joe/COBRA connection seems a bit forced as The Baroness (Ursula Corbero) arrives to move things along but it is mainly for the purpose of getting characters to do this and get that so the film can move towards the climactic action.

Samara Weaving does show up as Scarlett but she does not have a very large part in the story and aside from a few limited action moments; she seems to be more of the token G. I. Joe representation.

Golding and Hira are very good and their intertwined and complicated relationship is giving plenty of time to develop as their past is a large part of their futures and the film does a good job in explaining their past and future motivations.

The film blends Asian and Western film styles and in doing so creates an enjoyable film that for me was more enjoyable than the prior films in the series. To me those films focused mainly on action and this one was focused on developing characters.

While it remains to be seen what direction future films in the franchise will take; it would be interesting to see more of Snake Eyes story down the line.

3 stars out of 5.

review_title: This was not one for the records...
review_detailed_main:
Having grown up with the "G. I. Joe" cartoons on TV and always liked them, I must say that my expectations for this 2021 movie "Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins" weren't exactly sky high, given the previous live action movies based on the cartoons.

But still, of course I sat down to watch this movie and see what writers Evan Spiliotopoulos, Joe Shrapnel and Anna Waterhouse would come up with.

And while "Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins" certainly was a watchable movie, this was essentially a no-brainer. You just disconnect your brain, lean back and munch the popcorn while watching the action on the screen. In terms of proper contents for a deeper storyline or a fulfilling storyline, then "Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins" is not the movie you should watch. Nay, this was just mindless action with a "G. I. Joe" template dragged down over it to sell it to a wider audience.

I must admit that I sit here with a feeling of this being a rather unnecessary and unfulfilling movie, now that the movie came to an end. Sure, the movie was a cheesy action flick and watchable enough for what it turned out to be. But this was by no means an outstanding movie from director Robert Schwentke.

The action sequences in the movie are good, and they are what keeps the movie afloat. That, and also some nice visuals and special effects. But other than that, then this movie was a shallow shell.

The cast ensemble was interesting, though, I will say that much. I am not familiar with Henry Golding, but he did a good job at bringing Snake Eyes to life on the screen. And actor Andrew Koji was definitely a good choice for Stormshadow. Now, it was really great to see the likes of Iko Uwais and Haruka Abe in the movie as well.

I doubt that I will ever return to watch "Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins" a second time, because the storyline just barely had enough contents to support the first viewing.

My rating of "Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins" lands on a very mediocre five out of ten stars.

review_title: The IMAX experience made it better otherwise pretty good
review_detailed_main: Fairly exhilarating intense quite fast paced but very meh in many aspects! I understand the hate more than usual, Snake Eyes felt very stale and the best chunk of the movie is the last half hour. I loved the action more than anything otherwise I wouldn't recommend at all unless you watch purely for the thrill ride then you'd be pleased! I'm sure if there will be a sequel it'd be much better.

review_title: Worst of the year so far
review_detailed_main: Half of the time I don't know what is going on, there are many characters show up and don't do anything. There are very weak connections between the plots. Main character's growth is not persuasive, and it feels like he suddenly becomes great hero. I give one extra star for its Japanese elements.

review_title: An Origin Story Whose Eyes Fell From the Prize
review_detailed_main:
LIKES:

Decent Pace: The first G. I. Joe dragged its feet to get to the good parts and the second just sacrificed everything else, Snake Eyes origin managed to meet middle ground for this reviewer. An event that drives the character sets the stage for an emotional foundation, that dives into modern era and gets us into the chronicles of shadows that he will soon start writing. The movie then keeps a pace going that is fast enough to not be bogged down by details, but also not shallow to deprive us of a story. I enjoyed this balanced pace and the attempts at telling a story that had action support it.

The Special Effects/Sound Editing: For a big blockbuster, you always hope that special effects and sound effects to bring the full experience to the theater trip. Snake Eyes is a prime example of Hollywood's effects lab in full stride with high special effects moments, intense sound effects of sword clanging, explosion blasting, gun blazing goodness that we love to see in these kinds of film. There is seldom a quiet moment in this film and I really enjoyed the attention to detail to help keep things looking real without diving too much in CGI cheesiness. In addition, I appreciated that slow motion was only used a little bit here and there instead of at every turn (take a lesson Zack Snyder) utilized for only those choice moments to emphasize a kill or awesome move.

Story is better: I'm not saying it's gold or complete, but the story is miles better than what we got years ago with Channing Tatum. Characters don't feel too cartoony anymore, simplistic forms brought to real life and feeling out of place and forced for the sake of humor. Snake Eyes origins have a little more depth to his involvement, giving the character a darker set of morals to balance in his quest to be a hero. The ninja has deeper levels than simply slashing and gunning, and I liked seeing his skills develop with his character alongside several other members of the ninja league. Throw in the ties to the G. I. Joe universe and you again have a good potential restart like Bumblebee before it. The origins story certainly does have its limitations, but it still was lightyears better with its character and story development compared to the corny origin of Cobra commander in the previous installation.

The Action: The highlight for me is the action sequences in this film and how much it feels like something out of G. I Joe cartoons. Sword fights are the primary means for fighting in this installment, but it delivers on the promised cling clang, Kungfu, slash and slice that trailers showed. There is some bite to the fights, and lots of those ridiculous, off the wall moves that have been made famous from Bruce Lee movies that adds that campy edge to make it fun. I felt they managed to keep things relatively dynamic in terms of the arenas they fought and enjoyed getting distracted by the quick bouts in those pinnacle moments.

DISLIKES:

Some Of The Acting Is Cheesy: There are times that the acting drives down a different pathway, one that is less fun and weaker given the direction they were going. Mostly during the emotional moments, these soap opera like cries are funnier than emotional and thus feel out of place. Some temper tantrums and set up scenes are also a bit more melodramatic, trying to set up an epic fight that then sort of fizzles out in the long run. A few other characters need some more time to help get the full acting effect, but this is rather minor for me compared to some of the other limitations.

Story Limitations: While the story is an improvement, there are still things that need work in terms of making this a quality tale. Predictability is a big part, with so much foreshadowing and leading dialogue to help scream what is going to happen with our crew, especially if you are a GI Joe fan. Second is the fact that there is a lot of introductions in this origin movie and not necessarily all were needed to the extent we saw. Snake Eyes' journey into the ninja world feels a little rushed and simplified given the buildup, with several trials and training montages skipped for some reason. Meanwhile, the inner workings of the Yakuza are sort of blunted as well and the obsession of certain components sort of makes for a lame reason for why they are doing what they are doing. Throw in certain characters from the Joe universe making early, sometimes in your face, appearances and it again throws a wrench in the smooth workings of the machine this movie was starting to be. Sadly, the other thing I did not enjoy is the big plot device that sort of tied the arcs together. In terms of the cartoons, it could work when the war gets established and Cobra Commander starts to look for alternative options. However, this magical artifact that is in this film is sort of standing out given all the other avenues of technology and warfare they could have chosen. It makes the movie jump into the corny realm and away from the direction it was going. In addition, I believe there are those angry with the fact that Snake's new origins may be insulting to the good name of the character, and the purists who prefer him silent and stoic will most likely not enjoy the direction they took in this film.

The Action/Camera work: While I enjoy the action's pace, the sound effects, and the energy, I can't lie and say there was more coordination that was still needed. For one thing, more edge and suspense with the fights would have been nice, adding rivalry, stakes, and a few close calls that could have made them more exciting. The knowing that most if not all parties would survive thanks to that foreshadowing took a bit of that suspense away from me. Second, the fights could have evolved a little more past pure sword fighting, bleeding the gun play and sword fighting Snake will eventually find normal when working for the Joes. Third is more time with other characters showing their moments, as many of the extra characters had only fleeting glimpses of awesome moves when there could have been so much more merging of styles the way the Avengers did in their movies. Fourth, the unnecessary involvement of other Joe's characters sort of interrupts the flow of things, and though some cool moves could be seen, I would have liked them to not be randomly inserted into the fray with little logic or purpose. However, the biggest limitation is the camera work and the masking of the editing involved with the sequences. Why shaky camera syndrome and new angles switching is popular I don't know, but it got in the way of what could have been awesome displays of martial arts and sword play. Not the most nauseating, but still would work on full sequence shots and less editing to make it seem full sequences would be a major improvement.

The VERDICT: Snake Eyes was more enjoyable for me than I had expected and managed to bring some promising elements to the table should the G. I. Joe verse rev up. I liked Golding's class and poise, and I felt that there was plenty of time with many characters they introduced. Snake Eyes' journey to his ninja status has some heart and layers, helping give some better character development than the past. With a good pace and some action sequences that are very comic book like , with great sound effects/special effects flair, high energy, and keeping the movie going. Yet, the movie still has some work to do to get the universe set up to the crème de la crème it wants to achieve. The acting does fall into cheesy territory at times, with the story limitations forcing our group to have to go into soap opera drama levels that take ways from the better performances. This new origins tale does sort of squash Snake Eyes character that most know and has predictability patterns that mess up some things, but it's the fact they tried to cream so much into the movie again fails for this reviewer. As for the action game, the jittery camera and uneven editing take away from what could have been the next stage of action for this series, alongside unneeded interruptions from a fight that could have been the perfect bite to the Joe army. Overall though, it's fun and promising for G. I. Joe to return if they can help add some finesse to the foundation.

My scores are: Action/Adventure/Fantasy: 7.0 Movie Overall: 6.0 .

review_title: the rise of cobra has a better origin story for snake eyes
review_detailed_main: Honestly. Just watch that one. There's much better everything. Action. Plot. Better acting.

Great casting+Great story.

So many people complaining that this was not Snake Eyes..'he didn't wear his suit.' Boohoo you babies..this is how he became Snake Eyes and it opens it up for a great GIJoe movie..The action was great and fun..and I see people complaining about Snake getting hurt..um yeah..this is before he is the great ninja we seen in the books and cartoon..people don't start out being the best..quit your whining..its people like you complainers who wreck movies for others..this movie is part of a growing story..not the middle asshats.

review_title: Not Worth the $25 digital purchase but will stick with it.
review_detailed_main: A great selection of characters with a pretty weak origin story for one of the most decorated and favorable characters in G. I. Joe. Yakuza films are known for their organized crime actions and dealings but this movie had less to do with that. Was kinda weak to the lore and they kinda ruined the great action sequences with close-up shots and shaky cameras. I kinda get disappointed when a great fighting sequence gets cut for a new scene and gets you wondering why they didn't show the whole fight for the sequence to be memorable. Was a bit fun nonetheless and will stick with it....hope to see a sequel.

review_title: Really poor script and shaky cam

review_detailed_main: Interesting premise, some extremely cool set pieces and concepts, and adequate CG. However the film falls flat in execution - the plot is contrived, the fight scenes are badly shot with constant cut-aways that remove any sense of continuity or flow, and the actors looks bored throughout. If the actors in the film can't marshal more than a vague interest in what they are doing, how can an audience be expected to care? Ultimately an extremely frustrating film which rapidly outstays its welcome.

review_title: Should be called Storm Shadow: GI Joe Origins
Who exactly is the film aimed at?
review_detailed_main:
I came to this movie with low, low expectations as the first two GI Joe movies were abysmal. However as this was being touted as a kind of reboot of the series and would have a more serious tone I decided to give it the benefit of the doubt. Unfortunately Snake Eyes doesn't improve on the GI Joe films and is probably (if the film studios have any sense) what will bring to an end this franchise.

The tone of the film is jarring, it seems to want and try to be gritty but at the same time is cartoonishly over the top. It's too mature for kiddies but too ridiculous for adults so I have no idea who they're aiming the movie at!

The SFX are decent which stops it from getting 1 star but other than that avoid.

So for a movie seen at home on hbo its definitely worth it. Not for the picky movie critics, just for those who enjoy a packed action family movie. I have to admit that there is a twist in the movie that really got me surprised. The special affects are more for television and clearly not for cinema. However, the car chasing, the fight scenes, the flying fighters reminding you of matrix i kinda say, very well done. The story it's your typical "revenge will not bring anything good" but still that won't stop anyone to move forward until they hit a brick wall and realize.... "hey, maybe that wasn't a great idea". To summarize in my opinion it's a 6 stars movie and i will definitely watch a second part if they make one. Give it a chance but take it as it comes, just a family adventure movie.
We went to this movie excited about a stand alone Snake Eyes movie. We left after 30 minutes, that's how bad it is. We have never walked out of a movie before.

Having watched the orignal GI Joe movies, I can honestly say they shouldn't have messed with Snake Eyes' character or characteristics. Changing the story to suit a new movie with some terrible acting at times definitely made this a B Grade movie. I had high hopes for it but while there are some redeeming qualities, overall I was seriously disappointed.

It's the origins of G. I. Joe team member Snake Eyes (Henry Golding). Nobody asked for this. Nobody is really looking for this. The story is fine. It's a functional origins story if somewhat uninspired. Golding is fine. The actors are all fine. The action is fine but the constant CG work does make it repetitive. The last act drags as the repetitive action goes on and on. This is trying to set up for more G. I. Joe movies but that is unlikely to be successful.

review_title: Excellent cast and acting unfortunately with a quirky plot and filming style
review_detailed_main: The overall film, quality of acting, and development of the characters was exceptional. The interactions between Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow and their love/hate relationship was developed exceptionally well by both actors. The plot twists brought a level of depth that most movies of the genre fail to bring and it leaves the audience wondering who is the good guy multiple times through the film. The action sequences are incredible but unfortunately shot in a very shaky style that conflicted with the precision martial arts on display from nearly all the cast. It's a great film that could have been epic with better film crew! Lets hope they change for the next one!
The shaky camera and terrible electric bikes ruined this movie. It could have been so much better.

review_title: Not Even the Charming Henry Golding Can Save this Average Action Origin Story
review_detailed_main:
Good: Henry Golding is truly a star in this movie and would be a primary reason to watch it. A generic actor would not have the charm and wit, lending the movie to be a total wasteful action movie in 2021. The action is alright and uses A LOT of swords but is passable.

Bad: Writing is your average Ninja/Revenge flic. There is nothing new to the table and could have easily been made a couple of years ago.

Overall: A generic Summer-Action film that has nothing new except Golding, but even that is not enough to recommend to average moviegoers.

2.8/5.
Please dont waste your time and money, avoid it. Movie is very slow, no story, bad action scenes, good actors wasted.

review_title: This was complete waste of time.
review_detailed_main: Just watched this flop in theater,such a bad movie, the story is weak and shallow, acting is bad,no fighting in movie except few short scenes, no cool scenes, effects,nothing,waste of money and time,and you can guess every second what will happen in movie.

Gi Joe was a good film. So was the sequel. Snake eyes was a popular character among fans and so naturally too many years ago they have now made a prequel dedicated to the character that has nothing to do with the series. I thought the best thing about this was the cast. All had their own strengths and the shot of the main ones about to fight the bad guy was pretty bad ass. So when snake eyes was a kid he saw his father killed in front of his eyes. He grows and decides to find him while working at a fish depot. We get a little development in plot but there's nothing really and as. Origin film snake eyes becomes nothing more than a cash crab.

review_title: All the hype.....non of the bite
review_detailed_main:
With an opportunity to reboot and jumpstart a very popular franchise and one of the most popular characters of that era that can go toe to toe with ANY Maverl or DC character in terms of fan following, once again the studios have gone and done a bad job.

Rewriting the character into a nonsense backstory and creating a huge rivalry based on something that barelly involves our main character.

Also 2 guest cameos that make no sense why they are there.

In short......dont see this going forward so dont hold your breath for the next one.

GI Joe with Magic Mike was way better in terms of character backstory and development.

I've not got much to say about this film... I saw it the other night with my dad and when we walked out we both thought this film was just alright.

Overall 6/10 I would say don't buy it on 4K uhd just dvd or normal blu ray would be fine.

Some kind of prequel to the G. I. Joe films and one of the very worst I've seen in a long time. An awful, senseless, badly written and terribly directed action film with barely any kind of coherent action. Henry Golding is miscast and out of place as the hero and the likes of Iko Uwais and Peter Mensah, both long favourites of mine, totally wasted. I can truly say I didn't enjoy a single second of this one.

This movie had its heart is, a great martial arts action movie done in the style of Hong Kong cinema. We have not had something like this in the action movie genre in a very long time. I loved how the movie makers knew what they were going for and made sure you understood it was a Joe movie only really at the end of the movie. This makes me hopeful for this reboot. What other styles of film making will they introduce in this relaunch as they go further? #hopeful.

I think this was your average origin story, there was nothing special about it, and it wasn't abysmal. I think the cast was great, I think Henry Golding really made the role his. I also think the story was a bit weak, I think that the plot was basic, easy to predict and obviously been a fan of the franchise, there wasn't anything that really made shock or amaze. I think the action was decent, in the end this was your average origin story, and I would recommend if you want somewhere to start in the franchise.

Snake Eyes wears a mask. Snake Eyes does not speak. Snake Eyes is mysterious. So this is not Snake Eyes. What we have here is another case of a director being handed the key to a.franchise they do not understand. Completely forgettable.

Frankly, a strange movie and the scenario is so strange that you do not understand what they want from it, In general the movie tries to explain to you how to make your heart pure from malice and hate and that's all or the snake will eat you 🤣🤣🤣

review_title: Some pacing problems, but really fun take on the character.
review_detailed_main: Snake Eyes is the latest attempt at a G. I. Joe film, and does a pretty good job at giving a fresh take to the protagonist. However, it needed an extra 30 minutes to really flesh it out. Some elements happened way too fast and others were nonsensical. But not all is bad. Some old favorites are present, Storm Shadow steals the show, character development actually exists, cinematography is beautiful, and the acting is solid. I recommended if you are a fan of Snake Eyes, but not if you are a hardcore one.

review_title: A boring action film with no personality
review_detailed_main: The hyper-stylized end credits are the best part of the movie.

review_title: Plays better as a regular Martial Arts movie.
review_detailed_main:
Here's The 4K Lowedown on "Snake Eyes" (PG-13 - 2021 - 4K)

Genre: Fantasy/Comic My Score: 6.4

Cast=8 Acting=5 Plot=8 Ending=7 Story=5 Imagine=7 CGI=8 Pace=7 Comic=5 Funny=4

A man is welcomed into an ancient Japanese clan called the Arashikage after saving the life of their heir. With a roll of the dice...Snake Eyes is born.

"To avoid harm, you must first learn how you harm yourself." It's not saying much, but I liked this more than the other G. I. Joe movies. The cast was great and I liked the fight scenes...it seemed though they did not follow the origin story from the comic book well enough. If you take a few scenes out, you wouldn't know this was about Snake Eyes...I think I would enjoy it more as a regular martial arts movie.

Yes, the budget of this movie was 88 mil.

And yet, it feels like a direct to dvd/streaming second grade low budget action movie.

The first 30-40 min were not bad to be honest, some good action here and there but after that it went to full snooze mode. Lots of dull dialogues and 'fortune cookie' zen messages.

The plot was quite predictable and the actors were just reading lines without expressing much emotion.

Very forgettable.

Everything about this film was over the top. The acting was outlandish. The story was preposterous. The action was non-stop. The whole thing was cliche driven and extreme.

But through it all, I enjoyed it very much. I took it for what it was, a comic book story to appeal to your baser instincts; something not to be taken seriously or cerebral (and to it's credit, it didn't take itself seriously).

Definitely recommended; if, just for fun, action, and entertainment.

I stopped watching at the first shaky cam fight.

This is nauseating - not entertaining.

I won't waste my time with such dreck.

You shouldn't either.

review_title: Entertaining for non G.I. Joe fans
review_detailed_main:
I believe a lot of people who hate this movie might be fans of the G. I. Joe franchise so they already hated the idea of having an Asian Snake Eyes from the beginning. The story is vastly different from Snake Eyes origin story in the comic books so I get that.

But personally for me and my other friends who watched it? We don't care about G. I. Joe so what ever changes they made to the story didn't bother us. We wanted an entertaining film with a fine story, good acting and great action scenes and that's what we got.

Could it have been better? Yes absolutely. Samara Weaving's acting as Snake Eyes was weak compared to the west and the director went with 'shaky camera' at times. Fight scenes were cut off pretty often and that's a shame when you have the legendary Kenji Tanigaki as the fight choreographer (Kenshin movies).

This movie brings a pretty good story of G. I. Joe with Snake Eyes. It's filled with action, Kung Fu fighting style, and a pretty good sword fighting if you enjoy a very single Kung Fu fighting movies. Not bad Snake Eyes... not bad.

Snake Eyes is too violent to be a kids movie and too stupid to present a grown-up plot. It's cartoonish in all the wrong ways, without ever being surprising or even that entertaining. Lots of great talents are sacrificed to revive a dead franchise, and while the previous G. I. Joe films were stupid but lots of fun, this one is too high on stupid and too low on fun. Samara Weaving is in it for a hot minute, and focusing on her might have brought so much levity this film desperately needed, but alas the film is centered around Henry Golding who fails to bring much to the table. I give this film some points for some good action scenes, but none of them were good enough to justify my trip to the cinema.

Personally i do not believe in reviews because i feel it majorly relies on perspective. And i have never been drawn to write one, until now.

This is movie is painfully bad and i do not recommend this to anyone. The acting is bad, the story is understandable but poorly managed.

I'm sorry if this discourages anyone but you should be. Rightly so.

For the most part 'Snake Eyes' stays right in theme with the other two G. I. Joe entries. Unfortunately, that means it was super campy. I guess that's what they're going for, but it does make it somewhat difficult to watch. This was a failed opportunity to take the franchise in a new direction, like what 'Batman Begins' did for Batman after the extremely campy 'Batman & Robin'.

I've never been one to really criticize the shakey cam technique during action sequences, but boy was it noticeable in this one.

Henry Golding was fine, but it's clear they would like to do more films to continue to flesh out the Snake Eyes character, because it's still not the Snake Eyes I know. Though, I'm just not really sure it's worth it to be honest.

With some bad casting besides Andrew Koji, this movie is such a paint by the numbers "action" film that it says wait we have sequels coming by the end, which nobody will want after watching this uninspired superhero film. The original GI film was a masterpiece compared to this.

review_title: Andrew Koji saves this mess of a film
review_detailed_main:
Went to the cinema to see if Henry Golding could pull off being an action star. To me, he certainly does not. I don't get all the fuss about him. He is good looking sure but he is NOT a great actor. Charisma used to be about being compelling or having an intriguing energy - most people are mistaking charisma for charm. Yes he is quite charming but NO he is not charismatic. His acting feels fake...his accent is all over the place....he is not the Snake eyes people wanted.

Koji on the other hand was phenomenal...his acting was powerful, magnetic and has a depth to him. His physical skills clearly outshine Golding's too. Perhaps Koji looks too asian looking for Hollywood to be a lead...so we get Golding leading instead and Koji having to play second fiddle...although even then Koji manages to outshine him in my opinion. This is the Storm Shadow a lot of people wanted. Should have been called 'Storm Shadow'

The film however....god...when will hollywood get it right. Shaky cam, poor writing and so many other terrible decisions. Lets hope it bombs so the producers learn a thing or two - but let's face it...they probably wont.

The worst movie I had ever experienced in a theater, I even didn't stay till the end Repeated story with a very week drama , the action scene is not as expected, unrealistic, and a lot of action scenes dose not make sense.

The biggest let down for this film was the fact that they abandoned the true origin story completely. Snake eyes and Storm Shadow were raised together as children and then Storm betrays the clan and that's where they become enemies. Changing this ruined everything. The main leads playing the aforementioned characters do well but there are so many mixed directions about where the characters will go, especially Snake, it's hard to like either of them. The action was plentiful however, that fact that it was all an over-choreographed, quick-cut, shaky mess will leave you with more headaches than thrills. The rest of the cast do fine and the villain is okay but most were underutilized and in the case of Samara Weaving, she was completely miscast. If they had actually hit any marks along the way I would have been forgiving in some way but it was too long, too lame and too formulaic to like. The only good things were the sets and back drops and the lighting.
More than what I expected, with good representations of Japanese culture.

review_title: Snake may have Eyes but not much brain
review_detailed_main:
I've only seen the films and haven't watched the cartoons or source material so my opinion is purely based on the merits of the film itself.

Overall the film is entertaining enough, provided you treat it as a filler film...the main protagonist makes questionable decisions in the film and plot twists are almost as obvious as what happens if you get bitten by a poisonous snake.

Personally the most jarring aspect to me even as a non-Japanese is why in the world are people from a so called patriotic Japanese ancient clan driving around in Hyundais (non Japanese) cars....was the budgeting so tight they had to partner their marketing with a non-Japanese car manufacturer for the film? It may be a minor complaint but for me the credibility goes out the window with such obvious details that are just not thematic.

review_title: created an account just for this !
review_detailed_main: So i can rate it 1 star just for the agressive and highly abnoxious AD rate of this movie, disgusting.
Sorry duds... it's just disgusting. You ruined the whole series with this savage movie. Very disappointed...

review_title: Weakest G.I. Joe adaptation so far
review_detailed_main:
Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins is the weakest G. I. Joe adaptation so far with an extremely dumb plot and the G. I. Joe stuff feels pointless but it still manages to be a fun action thriller.

Henry Golding gives a great lead performance even if he doesn't feel like Snake Eyes by the end. Úrsula Corberó, Samara Weaving, Takehiro Hira and Iko Uwais are all really good and Andrew Koji is definitely the standout.

Robert Schwentke's direction is solid apart from the action sequences which, whilst extremely stylized and impactful, are hard to comprehend at times and too short. It's well paced and the music by Martin Todsharow is fantastic.

I think this is better than "G. I Joe Rise of Cobra" and a little bit better than "G. I Joe Retaliation", also Snake Eyes is my favorite character.

The choreographed fights for the action scenes is well done but its hard to see at times because the camera is shaky but when you can see it clearly, it looks pretty cool.

I like Henry Golding as Snake Eyes, he did pretty well for the origin of the character and the rest of the cast are ok.

As always it's Cobra that is the one starting their fight or war also recruiting Storm Shadow in the mid-credits scene, you see how Storm Shadow was betrayed by his own ninja clan and become the enemy for Snake Eyes in the other movies at the end.

This is a reboot of the story they told in the first two movies, but I still liked how they showed it in this.

review_title: Boring story, decent origin set up, and action.
review_detailed_main:
3 out of 5 stars.

Snake Eyes is a fair action film that is an origin story for Snake Eyes. It may seem like a disappointing origin set up. With the film having a boring revenge story. Decent action sequences. And flat script that makes the characters forgettable.

The plot follows Snake Eyes (Henry Goulding) ever since he was a kid. Witnessing his father being murdered. He plots a revenge scheme to find the killer. Even if he has to join a menacing clan. Until he escapes with Storm Shadow (Andrew Koji). Which he invites Snake Eyes to his family clan. Where he will master fighting skills and become part of the family. While Snake Eyes is keeping and searching for his fathers killer.

The plot is boring. A revenge story that feels flat. It does have some set up for G. I. Joes. Like a short introduction of Scarlett (Samara Weaving) and Baroness (Ursula Corbero). And hint of a shadowy organization like Cobras. The script does not help but give dull characters and a flat story.

Henry Goulding is great with the role. Andrew Koji is forgettable. Along with Ursula Corbero. Samara Weaving is decent with the character.

The action sequences is decent with its fair share of action. Director could have shot it better. It was exciting to see once. But forgettable after it is all over. There is a mid credit scene that plots away for another sequel.

Snake Eyes is an okay film which could have been better. But a far drop to setting expectations high for a franchise.

review_title: Couldn't even finish it. Horrible acting, horrible script, horrible accents.
Dont listen to the bad critics
review_detailed_main:
This movie is amazing, its action packed with an amazing cast and an intersting story we get to learn who Snake is and how he was become the person we see, he makes some bad choices but Thats a heros journy and he does everything in his Power to make things right. Its no Oscar or anything like that but it sets up the GI JOE Universe.

This is a mordern version of origin story to Snake eyes and its NOT like the 80s Cartoon nor is it related to the 2 movies that came before.... Go in with and open mind set and i would say You're going to have a good time, hope this is a start to a new Universe....

Found it (Dr.) Strange this movie, the BumbleBee of the 'Joes, didn't come out years ago. This felt very 2005.

One of the perks for me to see this movie was the breathtaking sight of Henry Golding, but he had to know, if this was successful, none of us would see OR hear him again. Honestly, since that's the case with the character - he's mute + never takes off his helmet, they might as well save money and recast him.

But, I digress. This movie was pretty good, beautifully shot and probably the best of the G. I. Joeverse. Also: it was horribly edited with action scenes at times incomprehensible and predictable as all hell. And I'm not just saying that because it's a prequel of sorts.

Bruce Wayne, sorry, I mean "Snake Eyes" sees his dad murdered right in front of him and spends his off-screen time growing into adulthood by seeking revenge and becoming a clawless Wolverine. Lucky for him, two different Japanese clans want to use him.

Cue music: Some of them want to use him. Some of them want to get used by him. Some of them want to abuse him. Some of them want to be abused.

Still fits. Anyways, my other draws for seeing this opening weekend: I played with, watched and read G. I. Joe as a child and Snake Eyes was always my favorite and the best-looking Asian actor/martial artist, Iko Uwais, had a part. Mercifully, Iko's in it a lot more than I expected. I thought he'd play a bit part, but he was a good scene stealer.

I liked the rest of the cast and characters, especially Tommy (the bro,) Takehiro (the Anti---hero,) Blind Master (the cliché,) Baroness (the always great bi+ch) and Scarlett (my favorite Babysitter.) They all did what they could with their roles as the story could've been better and took a long time to get where we knew it would evolve to.

So, despite feeling like the recent Black Widow - both 2021 "Origin" stories, but feel dated already - it's a fun action/adventure with tons of action and gorgeous Asian men.

***

Final Thoughts: I'd have to rewatch the first 2 - haven't in probably 7 or so years, but I'd have to say Snake Eyes was the best one. I recall not liking the 2nd one much and the first, I was a huge defender of. It was everything I'd hope the Transformers Movie would've been and more. (I grew up with both toys and liked Transformers way more than G. I. Joe, but with the movies, this series far outdid the terrible Michael Bay films.)

review_title: The writer should be ashamed of themselves

review_detailed_main: It's getting boring at the 30th minute, the casting is not suitable, the background is below standard, the storyline is to slow.

If you can accept that when Hollywood adapts a property it almost never stays 100% faithful to the source material then I think you'll have the right mindset to enjoy this film.

This is a reimagining of these characters that is faithful to the essence of the source material and I thought it played out well.

Let me just state flatly thou, that if you're expecting to see the version of Snake Eyes we're all familiar with and love... Then I would strongly suggest you readjust your expectations coming in. This is an origin story thru and thru!

The casting choices turned out to be spot on, Golding said Koji were fantastic together as the leads, and I thought Corbero's Baroness to be a marked improvement on what we got in Rise of Cobra! Weaving brought the heat as Scarlet as well, the only casting choice that is criminally under utilized was Uwais as the hard master...

If you're not familiar with Iko Uwais then check out "The Raid 2" or "The Night Comes for Us" and you'll understand! In a nutshell he's an AMAZING martial arts talent and isn't afforded a real moment to shine in this film given the caliber of action awesomeness he's known for.

The only criticism that I've read repeatedly that does have a bit of merit (imo) was the over editing on some of the fight sequences particularly in the beginning, but I didn't find this to be the case for the majority of the film.

Overall I think this film accomplishes what it set out to do: tell the origin of Snake Eyes AND set the table for future GIJOE films.

I enjoyed it and found this take on Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow's back story to be compelling and entertaining! Can't wait to see more!!
So what happend for that story we see in first movie of G. I. Joe?

review_title: When the trailer fails to captivate you

review_detailed_main: Snake eyes talk to much. And we already know his vack story. Why do it again?!!!

There is one sequence in the movie where Iko Uwais is surrounded by tens of people. But then the scene jumps to somewhere else and then comes back to the end where they are all lying dead around Iko. This is like casting Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool and making him a mute (oh, wait...). That's one simple example of how bad the movie is.

The entire movie looks like a tutorial on things that shouldn't be done in an action movie. The action doesn't register because the shots are shaky or/and too close. These tricks are employed when the actors are incapable of fast movements or doing action sequences. But in Snake Eyes the entire cast in the movie are martial dance experts (and Iko practically redefined action movies in his lean and mean Raid movies) and yet it feels like watching action in that last Star Wars movie.

Anyway, if you have nothing else to watch on a lazy Sunday afternoon, you can pick this movie. But you will be entertained only if you expect not much from the movie.
So there is only one word about this film, Movietastic! The action scenes and shootouts are just heavenly! Well done and fantastic! A must not only for fans!

review_title: Unnecessary retelling of a story that Rise of Cobra did well in just five minutes
review_detailed_main:
I previewed The Rise of Cobra for my neighbour's young teenage son in anticipation of seeing SNAKE EYES. The original G. I. Joe film got a lot of negative reviews, but I loved it. As one of those young males who scooped up both the 3-3/4" toy line and the Marvel comic books, the film version was definitely coloured by nostalgia. I was pleased that the boy next door liked that film as much as I did. The action was constant, the plot mostly made sense, and there were all kinds of colourful characters with rich back story that was laid out in fast-paced scenes. I willingly overlooked the physical impossibility of it all (sinking icebergs, anyone?) with the same spirit GI:Joe fans wrote to Marvel Comics to exchange plothole explanations for No-Prizes.

Snake Eyes couldn't be a more different experience. There were long, plodding scenes - and if they had been exposition, it might not have been bad. But it wasn't even that - they were long soliloquys with platitudes about honor and loyalty and honesty. The crux of the film is Snake Eyes facing three challenges to join a Japanese 'clan'. But none of it makes any sense. You have a sword fight on a Los Angeles pier (why wouldn't they just bring guns - I mean, the whole job at the pier was as a gun smuggler), and a magic jewel and some death defying motorcycle stunts. You have low-rent copies of the Baroness and Scarlet from the G. I. Joe films. The actors they selected have no gravitas at all (Yeah, it would be hard to match Siena Miller's performance in the original.) And you have a little wokeness thrown in; the African member of the family, the super grandma in charge (patriarchy=evil, matriarchy=good).

Wanted badly to like this one, but it was mostly just an incoherent mess, certainly in contrast to the character's original development in the comic books, which was echoed in Rise of Cobra in a couple of succinct flashbacks. Those flashbacks were far more entertaining than this, unfortunately.

Positives are the lead actor's acting and some nice visuals, particularly of Japan.

The most boring film this year. Nothing but an experience of eating popcorn in the dark whilst having your ears grated by the most cliche and predictable Japanese babble. You will end up leaving the theatre to either keep visiting the washroom or get more snacks and on coming back you will still fall asleep and curse why you wasted your time and money buying tickets to this movie.

If you expected anything but a GI Joe typical origin story action movie, you expected too much. That's all the one, two and three star reviews. They expected way too much. But it's a GI Joe movie. It's predictable, cheesy, and everyone has plot armor. But at least it's better than Rise of Cobra and Retaliation. That being said; the choreography is very good, the story isn't bad, and Henry Golding is a great Snake Eyes. So, if you're going to see this movie, expect the typical action movie. I'm excited for future installments.
The fight scenes are WAAAAAAY too busy, and the movie could have been 45 minutes shorter and the point would have been the same. The nostalgia is great, but that's about it.

review_title: This is an action genre junky fan's dream
review_detailed_main: Snake Eyes (2021) is a movie we saw in theatres the opening Friday of its release. The storyline follows an orphan who makes a living as an underground fighter. He befriends a man in charge of the future of his clan. The orphan is asked by a government agency to infiltrate his friends clan and steal a jewel. The orphan is torn between his friend and the government agency. This movie is directed by Robert Schwentke (Red) and stars Henry Golding (Crazy Rich Aliens), Andrew Koji (Fast and Furious 6), Peter Mensah (Spartacus), Úrsula Corberó (Money Heist) and Samara Weaving (Ready or Not). The storyline for this is very straightforward but fun for fans of the original animated series to watch unfold as traditional characters slowly get introduced into the storyline. I loved the action scenes throughout the movies. The street fights, sword fights, and action scenes on the motorcycles are all over the top and well done. Overall this is an action genre junky fans dream that I would score a solid 7/10.

review_title: The worst G.I. Joe movie EVER

review_detailed_main:

Throw in some CGI and over the top action like the previous films, and ultimately its a pretty good flick, people seem to be reviewing this film like its The Godfather 3 and they were expecting a masterpiece, its a G. I. JOE movie for goodness sake, it's a beer and pizza movie so enjoy it for what it is.
