review_title: This is not a G.I Joe film! It's a fraud Mockbuster
review_detailed_main:
First off lets start with this is not How Snake Eye's became Snake Eye's!!!

That was covered in a previous G. I. Joe film where Snake Eye's was a child in a monastery training along side with "Storm Shadow" and he was a Caucasian kid, not a Asian kid... Next there is no Arnie, Rambo, Willis, Stratham, The Rock, Dennis Quaid, Channing Tatum or any real stars like the first 3 movies???

In fact G. I. Joe isn't even mentioned until 9 mins before the end.

Where is the Plane?....Gross fraud that this is part of the G. I. Joe franchise...IT AIN'T!

Where do I begin... lets for a moment pretend this is not a G. I. Joe "origin" story, let's pretend this is the typical ninja story where there is trauma, sword skill development, Japanese lore, and some awesome ninja fights, and... it fails, it fails at even setting itself up.

The fight choreography is awful, most of the time you won't even know what is going on, it's poorly lit and has some awful camera shots that close up on a messy scene that doesn't make sense.

It almost felt like it had big budget issues, some scenes were poorly edited and the cinematography was lacking, only having a couple of shots I enjoyed.

Now, for the story this wasn't a good Joe's origin story, it was barely a ninja story, they just threw stuff in there that would remind you of G. I. Joe, but I prefer to not even remember the movies are related.

The villains are just as clichéd as you might think and the appearance of a beloved "La Casa de Papel" actress in Tokyo made me chuckle as every fan of the series will surely get that reference. Now the girl could barely walk with those shoes and that bothered me to no end.

Overall I didn't enjoy this movie at all, the pacing is awful, the fights are terrible and the script...I'm not even talking about it.

review_title: Good mini-boss but not the best

review_detailed_main: My first thought, after "Snake Eyes : G. I. Joe origins" ended ,was simple, I enjoyed it. It is fun, quick, action packed, and has enough character moments to satisfy its story. It also serves as a good starting point for possible G. I. Joe movies, if they ever come to be. Which I have doubt about. That's because the fun comes at a price, that price comes at a cost of logic and questionable direction. It's a shame that it's many fighting set pieces come at an over kinetic shakey cam and multiple quick edits. The camera whips and zooms in with every hit and you become dizzy and numb to it. Even more disappointing is the characters become increasingly super human as mystical elements start to rear their heads. These elements don't actually affect the characters, they stay human, but the plot starts acting like more is going on without telling us. This removes the weight behind each action and choice. And Most of those are bizarre and irrational. No one seems to be an actual good guy, well except Scarlett who shows up in an unnecessarily forced bathroom Brawl, placed just so we know that she's a badass. Still though I liked Henry Golding in the role even though he feels less like Snake Eyes then some fans will like. But if this is what the series could look like going forward, I see potential in its growth.

review_title: The importance of actors and scripts
review_detailed_main: Cringe worthy lines delivered by horrible acting shows just how important your actors and scripts are. One would think Director, Robert Schwentke would pave the way for better performances given his decent past movies. Well it was free for me. Money saved, time wasted.

This movie is way better than I expected! The plot is decent, explores the history of both Snake Eyes and storm shadow and how they were once brothers. See these two fighting side by side is really cool. Only problem I had was with some acting were awkward.

Two stars entirely for nice shots of Tokyo and the beautiful, medieval Japanese castle. The rest: no stars. A stupid script that makes no sense, ridiculous dialogue lines, and a bad director who doesn't know how to direct fighting scenes. Nothing to like or admire here, apart from nice vistas of Tokyo and the castle.

Snake Eyes/Storm Shadow Origin story really. It's about a middle of the pack action movie. Good fight scenes, but could have used better writing. If you like G. I. Joe then this wasn't a bad movie. I would recommend giving it a watch.

review_title: Shocking Truth Revealed - Men Don't Speak! And, The Human Race Nearly Pays The Price For Their Silence.
review_detailed_main:
Greetings And Salutations, and welcome to my review of Snake Eyes; here's the breakdown of my ratings:

Story: 1.00 Direction: 1.50 Pace: 1.50 Acting: 1.25 Enjoyment: 1.25

TOTAL: 6.50 out of 10.00

Snake Eyes is your typical Action Adventure film based on boys' dollies. I can't wait for the new Barbie origins movie to come out - Scarlet Johannson doing her best black widow but with blonde hair. Just joking, though, if any movie executives are out there and decide to nick my idea, I Copywrite the notion here and now :-)

The story isn't too terrible though it does possess one major flaw. After a young boy witnesses the murder of his father, he quests for revenge against the killer. He grows up into a martial arts expert kicking arse in underground tournaments. When one day, a stranger appears and offers him the whereabouts of the Daddy Slayer in return for his employment in the Yakuza. He is looking for a man with his skills. And this is where the predictable twists begin. Now, the major flaw in all of this is the surprising lack of communication. The Yakuza boss knows of the new guy's father because they ransacked his apartment and found the news clippings. Once we get into the conspiracies, it soon becomes evident that if Snake Eyes had just turned to his new best bud and said, "I saw my dad murdered, and I'm seeking revenge." The network of Ninjas who deal in spying and secrets could have easily helped him out - probably better than the Yakuza. And the story would have needed to take a different turn. So Snakey keeps his gob shut. Then he learns that the Ninjas aren't alone in their pursuit of peace; they are working alongside the GI Joes - an American/International information and military team. Come on - Snakey could have the Daddy Slayer in his hands before tea-time. Why do blokes have such a hard time opening up? I know - it's so the writers don't have to do any hard work thinking up new twists in the tale. Everybody could have lived happily ever after had Snakey spoken. That's not the only hindrance to the story. I was doing well until we got to the second of the three Ninja trials. What the bloody hell is that blue ball the blind master conjures up, and from where did it materialise? If there's magic now, why not use it against the attacking hordes. Send them all off to dreamland to face their deepest darkest fears. But sillier comes in the third trial and the shape of three mega-anacondas. These snakes are so massive I was wondering where they kept their chow. It was here I began to lose interest a tad.

Luckily though, the director is a dab hand at action scenes. I cannot fault his work in the slightest - There are stimulating camera angles - Everything is naturally lit and visible - There's a minimum of shaky camerawork - And most of the fight sequences are shot full-body. As for the tempo, it's a near-perfect blend of varied paces - giving the audience a visual rollercoaster ride of fascinating excitement. Sadly, some of these action segments are wholly unbelievable, especially the car transporter fight. There is no way they could battle on top of the cars on the upper level of the transporter. No sooner would they try standing up than the wind's force would throw them clear off the vehicle to be mowed down by passing traffic. But, hey, it looks good. Actually, it looks a tad off. The CGI shading is wrong; this is more evident during the motorbike segments of the scene. It gives an unrealistic air to them, which pulled me out of the film a little, which, in turn, harms the picture and the viewer's involvement.

The cast is more than respectable in their portrayals. Though, Henry Golding, as Snake Eyes, does possess a reoccurring accent. It's strange because I'm sure he's American, but something is going on with his voice, and it started to bug me towards the end of the film.

Snake Eyes was my Saturday morning breakfast viewing. And as such, my brain wasn't fully functional (still climbing of dreamland), which I found was a great way to watch the movie. If you like movies you don't need to think about because you merely want the excitement of the action, Snake Eyes is the flick to entertain you - It did me.

Please feel free to visit my Holding Out For A Hero and The Game Is Afoot lists to see where I ranked Snake Eyes.

Take Care & Stay Well.

review_title: Better than I had been led to believe
review_detailed_main:
It's a movie spinoff from a set of movies based on an ancient toy line. Measure your expectations and just chill.

Shakey cam? Dunno. I didn't notice, so perhaps I'm one of the billions who it doesn't enrage. I enjoyed the combat scenes, so... yeah.

The lead was a miscast. Peter Mensah and Iko Uwais were wasted. Úrsula Corberó was an engaging performer, though, again, wasted. Samara Weaving was, as expected, good. But, again, wasted, though I trust that she'll have a larger role in future movies.

Haruka Abe did very well in her role, but she got a lot of screen time to work with compared to the others.

My only big complaint about this movie is that it predominantly consists of sword fights, but there is no blood. If you're aiming for a young audience, don't use bladed weapons.

As a mainstream movie aimed at general audiences, I give this movie 5/10. Maybe 6. For a movie aimed at kids in order to sell toys, I give this movie 7/10.
Got a migrain watching this with all the sweeping and shaky camera footage, this is worse that cloverfield for the camera work.

review_title: A good traditional action movie that takes itself far too seriously.
review_detailed_main: A good old fashioned action movie that takes itself far too seriously and doesn't seem to have much to do with G. I. Joe. The story isn't complex and is lacking in scale, but it has lots of Japanese culture and style and plenty of fast paced and exciting action scenes. The acting and characters are ok, although some characters are brought in for little to no reason, and it lacks that spark that makes a good movie great.
Captain Duke Hauser would be rolling in his grave if he knew this film was made.

This movie is well acted, well written and...that's kind of where the good stuff ends. There are good visuals here but I think that's more inspiration from similar movies set in Japan (and other Kung Fu movies) and really Japan itself. I'm sure if you take a camera around Japan long enough you can get most of these shots anyways.

I do like the character development between Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow. I knew Henry was a good actor but Koji really held up his own considering nearly all of his scenes were opposite Henry. I felt that the movie overall was well cast. I wouldn't mind seeing these actors reprise their roles in future G. I. Joe movies. The story is well told but I'm thinking most people won't like the story. I can't get into details without spoilers.

I also want to mention that if you're a big G. I. Joe fan that this movie may not do much for you. The G. I. Joe elements felt wedged into the main story and could have easily been taken out. I do like the effort to have the tie-ins but it does feel like sequel-bating. Not everything can be a massive cinematic universe; Hollywood needs to calm down.

The worst offender is the action. It's not well coreographed nor well shot and edited poorly. It was so bad that it almost felt like they tried editing out a lot of the combat and just cut action scenes short for some reason. Does action look bad with Henry and they tried saving the movie? I guess we'll never know because there's so much shaky cam I could barely make out what was happening. I was wincing and shaking my head whenever another action scene came along; it was almost nauseating to watch.

Now that the character is established, I'm hoping that if there is a sequel that it will be in a much more digestable story. Also, since everyone is complaining about it, get an action director with a steady cam and pull the action scenes away from whichever editor chopped up these scenes.

(This is just my opinion you can think this movie is a masterpiece everyone has there own opinion and that's fine.)

The best aspect of the movie is the inclusion of Iko Uwais, cause I **** love that guy. If you wanna see a good action movie watch The Raid (2011). Before watching this movie in the cinema I made a bingo completely blind and got 10 out of 16 cliches, overused tropes, etc. Right. The ones I didn't get right were mostly about objectifying portrayals of women, so good job I guess. Getting back to the good aspects of the movie, I can count 5 if I'm generous, everything else is horrible or tiringly predictable. Worst of all not even the action is good. I can't think of a single thing this movie does that is unique. Now, many people would say that: "oh, it's just a popcorn movie", but there are already soo many of those, it is god damn time to make some actually good movies for a change. As for all the bad parts I don't even know where to start: the protagonist is unlikeable, the character development is forced and jarring; there is not even a single training sequence of snake eyes. IN AN ACTION MOVIE THAT IS MOST SIMILAR TO A **** SHONEN. He sucks at the start and sucks at the end. Performances are mediocre at best, music is... wait, what music, most characters have no character, it is all horrible. Please treat yourself to The Raid and The Raid 2.

It's a spectacle movie with a good performance by Henry Golding. If you come looking to be moved or be dazzled. This is the wrong movie for you. If you want just a fun time at the movies, this will do.

review_title: Huge disspaoinment. Lazy fight scenes and even worse plot.
review_detailed_main: Huge disappointment. Lazy fight scenes couldn't be saved by the even worse script and character development. A shame that a cool character had to go to absolute waste with this terrible film.

Since watching the first trailer I expected to be in for a great action packed movie but instead all I saw was bad acting, corny jokes and poorly executed action sequences. I'm still in shock from last night's disaster that I'm almost left speechless this morning.

review_title: Snake eyes is a jaw dropping gi joe summer flick

review_detailed_main: First off, I know nothing about GI Joe. Second, I was hesitant to go see it after all the negative reviews but was pleasantly surprised that it not that bad. The plot is average but I really don't expect much where action movies are concerned. I would say many of the fight scenes are done in an Asian style reminiscent of old Hong Kong movies from the eighties and nineties. This style is not for everyone, hence some low reviews. Both Henry Golding and Andrew Koji did a good job in their respective roles, even though I didn't care much for the other characters who were a bit cartoonish. I also was not a fan of the snake pit scenes which I found a bit cheesy. All that aside, I definitely think there are worse action movies out there.
I don't like the way he wanted to get revenge even in expense of other's lives.

review_title: Sorry Story + (Less than) Average Acting = Meh Movie
review_detailed_main:
I read the reviews before seeing this and they were, for the most part, on point. A movie detailing the growth of Snake Eyes froma martial arts novice to an unstoppable expert only matched by Storm Shadow would have been excellent. There is no growth here. The same physical skills he had when discovered are unchanged. Instead he has a change of heart and considering the fact he had his arse handed to him by other martial arts experts that is not a good thing. How did he become the bad@$$ we saw in GI Joe? This is not explained. The action scenes were serviceable but many times the reason for the fight left a lot to be desired (So much so I was tempted to give this a 3).

The acting seemed forced and cartoonish. It was like they knew this movie was based off of a cartoon/comic book and acted as if it was. I went in with low expectations and this movie was worse than I thought it would be.

If you are just looking for occasionally good action this may be the movie for you. I will just say that the best action took place in act 1.

Snake Eyes

I really enjoyed this marshal arts romp from start to finish and we really got a comprehensive origin story. To be frank Henry Golding has the look but not the depth of acting talent to have a movie rest solely upon him, this deficit was self-evident in Monsoon. However for this, quite superficial role, he was well cast and raised up his game from the level of eye candy!

So much was good, the contrast of good and evil, the fight sequences, fighting granny, brother chemistry, supernatural events, styling, scoring the list is endless. But to my mind what made this great was the tongue in cheek light touch of the script and direction.

I am not sure why there are so many mean reviews on here, but comic purists always find fault, well wake up and smell the coffee, art products must be judged on their individual merits as to whether they rise or fall, we must judge what is before us, not what we want or think should be before us, as this would be unfair!

The "spirit" brother Tommy, played by Andrew Koji was great as was the entire ensemble.

I wasn't expecting much but this movie pleasantly over-delivered. It was a slow start but rose to a crescendo! I'm giving this a firm 7 for pure entertainment.

review_title: Why did we lose the original backstory from the GI Joe Movie
review_detailed_main:
I don't understand why the compelling backstory was abandoned. We had a great story with Storm Shadow and Snake Eyes already in the movies.

As from this, the extremely limited action brought upon a bore fest for the kids, and some of the adults watching took naps with the dark filming and monotone whispers of the actors.

review_title: Fun karate movie, not a superhero flick
review_detailed_main: We liked it but only as a Jackie Chan type karate flick with ninjas and motorcycles and sword fights. It was fun but the middle dragged. Funny watching people who were dedicated to one thing flip flop their life mission over a misunderstanding or silliness.
Why would they film the fight scenes with shaky cam, it's hard to watch and made a bad movie even worse. Go ahead and skip this one and save yourself the headache.

review_title: Forgettable, but in the right hands could have been something.
review_detailed_main:
Apart from a couple of good moments, this film is completely forgettable. Watching this I could not help but compare it to similar action films featuring the Yakuza such as Black Rain and The Wolverine. Both these films were infinitely more original. Yes, even The Wolverine shines next to Snake eyes.

The plot, which is something about stealing a magic rock, is paper thin. In showing the feud between two organizations (one being Cobra), the writers could have chosen a more meaningful storyline. You just don't care about the resultant feud between Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow, which is such a big part of G. I. Joe mythos.

In addition, the two actresses playing Baroness and Scarlett are terrible. There is just no way you would want to see an origin story of Baroness or Scarlett if they were playing these parts.

Still, the film did have one good thing going for it. Andrew Koji as Storm Shadow.

Henry did a great job as Snake Eyes. I loved the opening before the credits when Henry thanked the audience for coming, and expressed how excited he was for everyone to see it. The funny part is, so many movies in the past didn't get rave reviews when they came out, yet became cult classics later.

Movie had a nice look overall, sets were nice.

Characters looked overall - similar enough to the source material...except for Snake Eyes. Snake Eyes is a blonde-haired, silent, mask wearing man with a disfigured face but has been replaced with a handsome man who talks often and doesn't wear a mask.

I think because I'm familiar with the 80's comics and original cartoon, I did have a desire to see a movie that was re-telling the stories I've read in the comics but have never seen in film. Well...I didn't get that.

The movie I did get is a totally different story. Not a bad story, but disappointing to those who didn't want a different story.

I believe I would've enjoyed this movie more if they just called it "Ninja Movie" and gave these characters different names. Atleast I wouldn't be judging it in a way that I'm comparing it to the source material. I know others feel this same way.

I'd still say it was an enjoyable, one-watch-movie that you can go see on the big screen. Just don't expect a GI Joe story we know. I won't ever watch it again. But not awful.

It's slick enough and the acting and look is fine.

No believability at any stage, meaning you always have that sense that none of the fight scenes or other elements could possibly be real. You know going in it won't be a great movie and I expected to switch it off halfway through but ended up watching it to the end. Feeling a little stupid for doing so but we just didn't hate it. So it's rubbish but well made rubbish. Amongst the many things you can't believe is that Japanese gangsters run around with samurai swords rather than glocks. Set up for a sequel which shouldn't get made but if it does - we won't bother.

Story line: disgusting and used story line which is seen in various movies before.

Acting: omg!!! Super foul acting.

review_title: My thoughts on snake eyes minor spoilers
Bad movie I never seen before
Far below GI Joe movie quality
review_detailed_main:
The tech are all nice but the story under average quality.

If compared to GI Joe, this is really dissapointed. If compared to other action movies, this is just average.

Max I give is 6.3/10.

Already as a child I played with G. I. Joe figures so this movie was a must see. I have to say the title is interesting and the trailer promised good entertainment.

This movie tells how the two ninjas Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow met and how it all began. Very fascinating how the Arashikage clan has been shown and how they train ninjas. Some sort of mythical creatures have even been shown to be involved. This scene was very interesting and well done. The fights and shootouts have been made challenging and are of the highest quality. I have to say a lot of interesting characters appear in this movie. Cobra and G. I. Joe are not missing here either.

A very great movie about ninjas and I enjoyed it, even went to the cinema. From me top rating for a great performance.

review_title: Set alarm for 2 hours, you may fall in sleep
review_detailed_main: I hoped and waited so long for the next G. I. Joe movie but now having frustration indeed. The image of Snake Eyes in me was so cool in every act he made but now just only drown in revenge and dump.

The good guy has no honor throughout the movie and doesn't redeem himself in the end, but we're supposed to think he's the good guy. This movie could have done without the ridiculous snakes, as they were already stretching things with the crystal that had special powers.

Also, this movie would have been perfectly fine with an all-Asian cast, but they had to throw in 1 person in an unrealistic role as a master to check off a quota. And, they had 2 females from another demographic, but not a single male from that group. I'll bet you can guess which one without even watching the movie. When they constantly do this in such an obvious manner it overpowers the plot, as Hollywood's underlying social agenda comes to the forefront in an obnoxious way.

I don't like when people sale that because something isn't great that it's bad, so I won't say it's bad (it's not), but it's just not great. It must be hard to make a great movie though. Just ask the studios that sought Hitchcock to make their movies (I still don't think any director has made as many as him -- at least not theatrical blockbusters).

Anyway, this movie I can sum up in two words: dialogue heavy.

That's it. The parts that aren't dialogue heavy are pretty good.

Casting wasn't my favorite, but their acting was alright.

review_title: The trailer is the best part of this time waster!
review_detailed_main: Avoid... tired and tiringly derivative yawn-fest...two hours of your life that you won't get back.

review_title: good action and storytelling, though a bit topsy turvy at times; solid acting saves
review_detailed_main: Seemingly disregarding the "origins" of Snake Eyes in the first G. I. Joe (2009) in order to tell an even more in depth and dare I say charismatic background story, this movie paints a vivid picture well enough with crisp and sometimes colorful cinematography, a fairly simple plot, and even more interesting characters. The naïveté of some of them gets a little tiring by the third act, and how they make decisions, given the evidence of past consequences, seemed silly and unrealistic. But hey! It's based on a toy made into a cartoon, so, whatever. I get people giving this a 6 or even a 5, but a 4? Grow up. This franchise has experienced a stage of evolution that I'm certain Hasbro circa 1964 could've never even dreamt of. My only validifying acknowledgement of fan complaints is Snake Eyes not being, well, Snake Eyes (aesthetically), throughout the entire movie. He's shown on movie posters with the full getup and helmet, but that's absent in the film, except for a brief scene. Nonetheless, the progression of character development, especially by Andrew Koji, was very entertaining. As a Baroness "fan" myself, I was disappointed in her depiction, but it doesn't affect my rating at all. The movie as a whole deserves nothing lower than a 5.5.

review_title: Who ever wrote this Movie never watched the GI Joe movies!
review_detailed_main: Story completely off the rail, makes very little sense, a mystical stone with magic powers, that existed before GI Joe movies but Cobra never tried to get again? Guess ok movie if you never watched GI Joe movies, the technology in the movie is more advanced than in the old GI Joe movies. I can only assume after watching this they plan to remake the GI Joe movies to better align with this movie. Wonder how many characters they will change in the new remakes any guesses on how many of the cast will now be gay? Seems every movie and TV show someone is now gay! Maybe Jane?

review_title: Good action movie, not great Snake Eyes movie
review_detailed_main:
This is not a bad movie. The problem is that it is not a great Snake eyes movie either. The fist thing someone notice is that the main character is portrayed by an Asian actor instead of his western origin. This is not necessary bad but it may take you sometime to process it.

Snake eyes is a skillful, cunning and accomplished character and all these are fulfiled at some level. However there are many unanswered questions regarding character's past and his training as a kid or his oath of silence. We see an already grown Snake eyes that sometimes seems powereless against other fighters and other masters despite that he is considered to be a grand master himself, expert in a dozen of martial arts. On the other hand there is some nice action that includes not bad choreographies and there is a decent plot that brings some surprises to the audience.

Snakeeyes fans may not get fully satisfied but they may appreciate and enjoy that movie for its plot and its pace.

This was very mediocre at best.

So, you've seen all those trailers that they released for this movie? Well, then you've seen all the action scenes this thing has to offer.

The rest is going to be an exposition scene, after exposition scene, after exposition scene, after exposition scene.. enjoy! :)

I enjoyed it, it has lots of action and visual effects were good! Henry Golding's character as Snake Eyes is surprisingly good and way better from his previous films.

Some scenes are quite dragging, but it compensate to keep your eyes on the screen still.

Overall, a movie worth watching!

review_title: Not bad for an Airplane movie
review_detailed_main: Locked in and needing to watch something. No prior knowledge of "Snake Eyes" but Henry Golding seems too old (34 yrs) for the character as written. Tons of yakuza henchmen prove to be pretty inept with their katana. Starts out as a comic-booky yakuza thriller then some magic stuff happens and the "Joes" and "Cobra" are introduced. I guess a sequel is planned based on the black and white ending.

The title of the movie is literally apropos w/ the content. I remember when the Marvel comic G. I. Joe #21, March 1984, The Origin of Snake Eyes came out... it was a TRULY an absolute thing of beauty! It was the 1st time there were NO words used in a comic book... just storyboarded pics. Now THAT was truly innovative... & the story was exceptional... even w/ the use of NO words! Everything about this movie was good all right... good & terrible. Horrible storyline... craptacular acting... just consistently subpar across the board. It doesn't even address why Snake Eyes never speaks, for crying out loud!!! Horrible direction to move the franchise, b/c Snake Eyes is w/o a doubt one of THE BEST characters, in the Joe fold. This movie is an absolute discredit & disgrace to both the mystique & mist that Snake Eyes is shrouded in!

review_detailed_main: I quite enjoyed this movie. I adored the fight scenes, but thought the storyline was dragging at times, possibly because it lacked depth. However, I hope there's a sequel as I think there's potential here.

Action set pieces was average at best, nothing spectacular to remember. I am disappointed sorry.

But it works well enough to move along until the action starts. I would be interested in a. G.i. Movie with the cast that's been introduced and more, but doubt that happens with poor box office. Unfortunate.

I've been a GI Joe fan as long as I can remember and Snake-eyes is my all time favorite. This is NOT Snake-eyes' back story. The movie itself would be tolerable if it wasn't associated with GI Joe. I strongly recommend reading "Snake-eyes declassified" if you want the real story of Snake-eyes. The real story is so much better than whatever this was.

Reset and try again.

The action sequences were ok a clear 5 out of 10 the dialogue had too many dragging points and poor story line ill give that a clear 3/10 The major issue I personally have with is the clear deviation from the whole plot of the original story told in the GI Joe.
I never saw the first 2, but this one was entertaining and the action and acting was great. Plus, Henry Golding is easy on the eyes.

With all the talent assembled in this movie that was the best they could come up with? Did the writer even know anything about GI Joe, or it's characters? review_title: The Thrilling Adventure Of A Lifetime And The Perfect Origin Story
review_detailed_main:
Snake Eyes: G. I. Origins is the thrilling adventure of a lifetime and the perfect origin story to such a beloved character. With motorcycles, swords and a mystical gem - you will be a part of an incredible mission.

The movie is a spin-off around the character of Snake Eyes (Henry Golding). Holding onto the trauma of his father being murdered, Snake Eyes is on the hunt for his father's killer. He trains with the Arashikage clan to become a top ninja. Meanwhile, he makes a deal with some unlikely allies to find his dad's murderer.

Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins is an action-packed movie and is not to be missed. The fight scenes are incredibly filmed, using long one-take shots to capture the film's actors fighting with swords. The cinematography is iconic, with some night scenes shot with bright neon lights and others with a calming, peaceful, bright light. It's so cool to watch modern-day ninjas on motorcycles fighting one another on the streets. This film is perfect for fans all around the world that enjoy amazing battle sequences, especially for G. I. Joe fans. Familiar faces are shown like the Baroness and Kenta. We also see a teaser for Snake Eyes' most popular villain, which leaves the movie open for a very exciting sequel. The film is a wonderful origin story, telling the tale of Snake Eyes, showing just how he became affiliated with the Joes and where he's off to next, while sprinkling in some major plot twists.

The moral of the story is to trust yourself and always do the right thing. Many times Snake Eyes is tempted to kill his father's killer and throughout the film he learns the meaning of honor - to others and yourself - and makes a surprising choice. He also learns how to find inner peace with many of the things he's done and moves on to the next chapter of his life.

I give Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 13 to 18 plus adults. It is available only in theaters July 23, 2021.

By Heather S., KIDS FIRST!

Snake Eyes: GI Joe Origins is a good movie that could have been better had the filmmakers decided to build the universe and give meaning to the mask. Henry Goulding is fantastic as Snake-Eyes, and the social media whining about his ethnicity is the kind of stuff that's suited for less evolved minds, so I have no patience for that complaint. But for the fan who is concerned about the core story of Snake Eyes as a disfigured military veteran, that is a valid concern that alters the dramatic tension of this film.

The Good: The Modified Origin Snake Eyes: GI Joe Origins works as an astonishing Yakuza tale with the looming influence of COBRA. Snake Eyes and Tommy (who is later revealed as Storm Shadow in the film's trailer) have a fraught brotherly relationship that allows the orphaned mix martial arts fighter to join a secret clan of ninjas that protect society. There's the usual test of character trails you've seen in many martial arts films, and these are unique in their own right. In the dual-agent nature of Snake Eyes and Storm Shadows' relationship and the betrayals that underlie their relationships, the story is the strongest.

The Bad: The Introduction of GI Joe Scarlett O'Hara's intro is a direct rip-off from Black Widow's Avenger's interrogation scene. And Scarlett and the Baronesses sultry femme fatale act is a bit dated, overacted, and feels out of place in this film. You welcome their presence because it connects the universe, but at the same time, it's so poorly utilized that you don't care at all other than the first few moments they appear.

I bring up Scarlett because fans of the comics and the 80's TV series know there's a strong bond between her and Snake Eyes. At no point do you get the sense that these two will become lifelong besties. They are as disconnected as two strangers on Twitter. And this is where the decision to change his origin story hurts the film. In the comics, Snake Eyes saves Scarlett during a helicopter crash, resulting in disfigurement and loss of speech. In the later years, she goes with him to experiment with plastic surgery procedures as Snake Eyes longs to have a love life of his own. I'm sure the producers didn't want to scar Henry Goulding's beautiful face. Still, the absence of that history makes their relationship topical and the arrival of his acclaimed mask...well, meaningless.

The Ugly The plot has a lot going for it when you pay attention to the themes the director is trying to convey. The conflicted nature of Snake Eyes makes him a bit of a jerk but still, one we can empathize with him. Where the story goes wrong is the introduction of the infamous secret weapon that you expect in a GI Joe movie, but it's so poorly introduced that it feels like an afterthought to create a more great third act. Another exploit of the snake theme already lies in a film about a man named Snake Eyes with an enemy known as Cobra. It's a bit hokey and unnecessary to the film; it also shows a lack of creativity by the filmmakers. The film also misses the mark to make the universe feel bigger. It's a smaller self-contained story which is fine, but it doesn't do enough to make you want to know more about the world awaiting Snake Eye's future.

Overall: An fun pop-corn movie While it may seem like I'm hard on the movie, I'm rooting for it because I am a huge fan of GI Joe. A trip to my garage will reveal thousands of dollars of collectibles tied to that franchise. But Hasbro still hasn't figured out how to use this franchise in a way that makes it to the next level. Because there is a lot that's done well in this film, the cinematography is just suitable for this world--gritty enough to add tension but stylish enough to feel like a comic-book-themed universe. The actors are practical, not perfect. And the action is reasonably well done. So there's still a lot of work to be done before GI Joe lands it big at the box office.
I expected more and I think the film could not show itself well and does not fascinate the viewer.

review_title: Poorly written and even poorer performance
review_detailed_main: Truly dissapointing. Poorly written and even poorer performance.

review_title: This film is potentially entertaining for those who've just heard of "Snake Eyes"
review_detailed_main: For those unfamiliar with the character, the film can be quite entertaining and fun to watch especially if you're into movie genres packed with action scenes, sword fights, mixed with bits of comedic elements. The movie itself was very good, the fight scenes were well-choreographed, the actors played their roles quite well, and the plot of the story itself is enjoyable. However, considering that the movie is titled "snake eyes", the writers and director clearly messed up the whole movie by changing the entire narrative. Instead of following what was initially intended in the comics, they completely rewrote the entire story of the character and most fans clearly do not approve.
Storyline is so bad and not making any sense at all. Really really not worth it to watch.

Story is not matching to GI Joes, snake eyes is the part of GI Joes but on this movie snake eyes fighting style is different. Ninja style fighting style.

1 - why snake eyes doesn't speak in the past movie.

2 - why Ninja's master killed.

review_title: Terrible writing and storytelling; shallow acting
review_detailed_main:
I'm a big action movie fan and not even the action scenes were satisfying.

The writing was terribly cheesy and predictive, and the acting was subpart at best. I feel like the ONLY portion of this movie that should get a shoutout is the costume designer.

And the villain... oh god, the 'villain'... His use of the 'jewel' was equal to Thanos having the power stone and using it to open a jar... I wish I could get my time back.

SNAKE EYES is a great origin story and will help reboot and dying series. Henry Goulding and Andrew Koji are both quite good and help sell the picture. This is not your old GI JOE storyline but a new revamp on the series. For all the haters I gave this a 10 because most if them haven't even seen the movie!

Its seems like the majority of User Reviews on this once great site for cinephiles, dont understand the definition of an ORIGINS STORY.

Honestly, Im not shocked by anything anymore, my country went from a Quota filling President, to a Celeb President, to one who is senile and starting to suffer from Dementia, all in a period of 5 years. Social media regularly outs many in our culture as entitled, ignorant, and entirely self-absorbed. I should have known better, reading all the reviews I thought the movie was going to be a major bomb, I mean Suicide Squad levels of cinematic malaise and incompetence.

Then I watched it and two things stood out, other than Samara Weaving, (Hugo Weavings niece) not to many Americants are going to recognize this Asian heavy cast, save for maybe Uko Uwias, which is great! A Yakuza movie SHOULD be set in Japan and have a majority Asian actors.

The second issue is at time the movie seems like an A- or B+ production, and that is going to upset the clueless, Social Media crowd, who think every rebooted hot property should have at minimum, $200 million dollar budgets, and a script that follows the Kevin Fiege way.

No thanks to corporate made "Happy Meal" movies, and while this isnt a top notch Hollywood production, I enjoyed this more way more than WW84 or the last 3 Marvel produced movies I've seen.

While previous attempts at GI Joe movies were as successful as a one-legged dog in a jumping context, Snake Eyes brought the hope that a prequel origin story might help to reboot the story and provide some level of comfort to us poor 80s fan kids crashing to the ground. The result was a mixed salad of poor writing, pitiful dialogue, freshman level acting, and a dull storyline.

During one shot we were exposed to the first glimpse of the infamous Cobra logo on the inside of a crate full of weapons. That and that alone was the only element that peaked my interest in what became two hours of me looking at my watch and being thankful that I only paid for the matinee.

What will it take for someone to put together a script that actually does justice to the GI Joe genre? Maybe Disney should just buy the label up and create a Joe Universe (GIJU) in which we can see the characters truly develop and the creation of a world that brings to life the GI Joe/Cobra battle on a true global scale.

I have never written any reviews in my life, but i had to for this one.

Last night i watched this movie and was so impressed by the makers in the first half and so astonished that how did they fall face first in the second half? Its got to be written by 2 different people. It was 2 different movies for me. The movie doesn't live up to its standards and character their morals in the 2nd half. 1st half: KungFu Panda less the comedy + Dark Night rises 2nd half KungFu Panda gone rogue made by children

Severely disappointed would give it negative stars if possible.

review_title: It's quite bored on the last 40 minutes of the movie
review_detailed_main: From the beginning until 40 minutes before this movie ends, the storyline still good. But for the last 40 minutes, it makes me bored. Henry Goulding seems are not strong and though enough to portrayed Snake Eyes character.

5/10 - what could've been something really exhilarating and left you wanting more, this action blockbuster wasted the talents of its cast, gave little worth remembering, and failed to give the franchise the jolt it needed.

I am of course just playing ... ok no pun intended and no more jokes about ... well toys. Probably - kidding aside, the movie is decent overall. Though I am not aware of much when it comes to the GI Joe franchise ... I have seen the two previous real life movies ... liked one better than the other - this one .. well it meant well! Good intentions (again no pun intended and no offense to the bad guys in this either) and all that.

The acting is ok considering what the movie is (genre wise). Henry surely was quite happy to get the role - if you are not too happy about the end result, I am quite certain that it is not his fault or you will not blame him (at least not mainly).

The action is well choreographed - the story is quite paper thin, but I don't think people expect anything different. Be aware what this will serve you ... and deal or rather decide if you want to watch or not.

review_title: The action scenes destroyed this film
review_detailed_main: Decent script, awesome performance by Andrew Koji, fighting scenes a mess, that shaky camera was very dumb and hard to follow.

This film is not the greatest by any means. As a GI Joe movie.... It is horrible, like literally goes against everything snake eyes is as a character. The writers read his character origins and said "let's not do that."

As an action film though it's not terrible, like if it was just a random guy with this story then it's decent but still has some very questionable moments that make you question how stupid the writers have to be.

Absolute nonsense!

Don't see it else u will regret spending your money on it.

I've watched the previous films, and this one is quite refreshing to see! Also, whoever was in charge of the sets, props, and costumes, did an excellent job! You could see that they had studied and really paid attention to the details of the culture.

The actor's performance where good! I just hoped that they have written the story a little better! But hey, the good outweighs this!

review_title: Weak but ok for an outing.
review_detailed_main:
I know very little of Snake Eyes so my review is based soley on this movie.

6/10

Shakey camera syndrome from the outset to offset the more budget constrained cinematics. If you can withstand it. Then this movie will offer a basic story with somewhat interesting characters & fight scenes.

Do not expect a blockbuster. However, for a budget movie. It sets out to tell a story & does so. Albeit a little confused at first telling. It soon clears things up about fifteen minutes later.

Throw in Hollywood special effects with some humour & you have something to watch whilst you eat your snacks.

Enjoy.

review_title: Should have read the reviews before wasting my time
review_detailed_main: Trailers were so much better than the actual movie. Wooden acting and poor directing. Makes me yearn for an intelligent movie. This is a waste of time. Don't bother. Ninja Assassins was much better if you're in the mood for Ninja films.

review_title: What happened to the real snake eyes ??
Worth a good watch but this movie is not worthy of the title...
review_detailed_main:
This movie is bogged down by the sheer pressure of being about Snake Eyes movie and the GI Joe squad is so eager to jump in the movie that it's basically shoehorning in reminders that this is a GI Joe franchise.

The plot is overly complicated. If you want an origin story then keep it simple. Save your Marvel-like story ideas after you passed the first Iron Man story at least.

So the story is too hard to follow. Do the characters make sense? No, not really either. One of the strangest choices of casting. Most if the characters are so obviously american that in Japan, in a secluded clan of ninjas, you can hear west coast accents. Was getting some Japanese actors too hard? Also I can't shake this feeling of hypocrisy from the studio: too afraid to hire a blond american for the role, but hiring a South Asian actor, who is clearly recognizable in Japan, to play a ninja while in a clan the seems to speak more English than Japanese. Is this not cultural appropriation and stereotype? I wonder... i haven't felt this level of cringe since Scarlett Johnson was cast as Major Motoko.
They had 40 years of mythology to draw from and disregarded pretty much all of it. This barely resembles him. It's, again, Hollywood ruining a character by rewriting his entire history.

review_title: They attempted but they didn't make it.
review_detailed_main: It's really nice to know he can talk after everything,but I enjoyed the story line and it wasn't really that bad.

review_title: Did they read the comics first!?!?!
review_detailed_main:
Let's just be clear from the beginning, snakes eyes was always a gaijin (foreigner), storm shadow turned against the family and killed both there master as he felt the master favoured snake eyes. Thats the main reason for the hatred between the too main characters, I was generally looking forward to seeing this story being told, what I got was a story so bad, so predictable, a poorly delivered I'm pretty sure we won't be seeing anymore G. I Joe origin movies.

A complete miss from the source material, some pretty poor fake accents and to top it all off they missed one of the most defining characteristics , the fact snake eyes DOESN'T SPEAK!!!! ( I get it would of been harder to do a film where the main character doesn't speak but they could've led us to why he doesn't let's be fair some of the scenes where so bad they could've done with the silence.

Huge fail in my eyes.

Watched this movie on my birthday and enjoyed it. It was entertaining with some good acting and nice action sequences.

Storyline is a bit weak and I know a lot of people didn't like the camera work much, thou it didn't bother me as much.

All in all a decent film and worth a watch if you want to know how Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow became what they are.

7/10 from me and with a better director this movie could have been so much better.

GI Joe movies were mindless fun. Not to be taken seriously.

I remember watching them with my young son and he always like Snake Eyes.

So here is an origin movie with a new actor replacing Snake Eyes.

Snake Eyes (Henry Golding) saw his father being executed as a boy. Since then he has vowed revenge.

Twenty years he is a drifter who makes ends meet as an underground fighter.

He joins a Yakuza gang led by Kenta who promises Snake Eyes that he can find the identity of his dad's killer.

Snake Eyes infiltrates a Japanese ninja clan by saving the life of Tommy Arashikage.

However he soon learns the costs of betrayal as he is left having to choose between being a GI Joe agent or being a Cobra operative.

This is certainly brainless mainly due to a lukewarm script. It did not take much to figure who would be behind Snake Eyes father' death.

Some of the action is fast and furious and suitable for a family friendly audience. There is a hint of Harry Potter with the giant snakes and magical jewel.

Unfortunately too much of the action takes place in murkiness.

Storm shadow and snake eyes were everything I had hoped they would be in their origin story!!

The plot was predictable(main reason for 8/10) but still exciting and enjoyable watch!

The actors casted as the baroness and scarlet were not on the same level as Henry Golding(Snake eyes) and Andrew Koji (Storm Shadow)

review_title: Poor reboot. Just tell the story correctly, it's what people want'
review_detailed_main: Poor and lazy. I get it's a reboot but they couldn't get ONE original actor to reprise a roll? These reboots always suck. People would LOVE it if you just told the story, we'd watch and relive our childhoods. Changing the plot, the characters, and backgrounds is just bad. We like them because we know the story already. This is why Marvel beats DC. DC and their CONSTANT reboots!! How many times do I gotta see Batmans' parents die? Marvel just trucks along and doesn't go back and money grab. Just stick to they story line we love and we'll come see it. Changing things only invites people like me to dump on it.

This was supposed to be a banger movie, following the long wait for a G. I Joe movie, since the last. But this was a horrible movie. Fight scenes too fake, interactions too childish. And the storyline is just not it. When watching G. I Joe retaliation, Snake eyes and Tommy were raised together, Tommy went astry and so forth, here, i dont even know.

Snakes eyes has not said a single word in G. I Joe, yet he's talkative here,. You messed up the storyline. Where is the nano tech? Im sorry to say but, you messed up a supposed to be great movie.

Okay, there are a few things I want to be clear first.

1. I'm rating this as a fan of Snake-Eyes from the late 70's.

2. The fault of this monstrosity is not due to the acting.

Alright, so this is NOT the Snake-Eyes origin. This is pretty far from it. This is a Snake-Eyes "inspired" movie. Whomever wrote this pile, either had no clue as to who the characters really were... or simple didn't give a damn and disrespect them and the fans.

If you have been a fan of Snake-Eyes or G. I. Joe in general, from the original comics or cartoon, then do not watch this. If you weren't or couldn't care less about it, I still warn you this is not a good movie. The writing really is atrocious. There are holes all over the place, and even suspending your disbelief will not allow you to accept a lot of what they try to shove down your throat.

The action could be good, if they let you see it. Whomever decided that these camera shots would lend well to the action, didn't have a clue. It hides a lot of the action, which the actors seemed to be able to provide. So why take away from that?

I will say Golding's accent came out way to often. Which is one critique I would provide. That said, the actors all seemed to do their jobs well, despite the terrible writing.

The cheesy 80's action movie item of power was just so cringeworthy, that you simply lose all hope that they maybe... just maybe, pull this out of the toilet and turn it around. Which may be a good thing, as any more disappointment of this sacrilege could push you to slit your proverbial wrists to put yourself out of your misery.

In the end, I wouldn't suggest this to anyone. And to the studio, don't ever let whomever wrote this garbage... to ever write for this kind of movie again. Don't disrespect the IP or the fans like this. You want our money, but you've lost our trust. Why would we want to watch anything more you put out? I know you won't be getting my money again. Not unless I find out you knock the next 2-3 out of the park. You didn't even hit the ball on this one.

review_title: Didn't satisfy my thirst for martial arts action
review_detailed_main:
From the little I remember from G. I. joe rise of the cobra, snake eyes was one of my favourite characters, because of his ninja fighting style. Being a martial arts fan, I was excited about a movie that focused on him. Not what I was hoping for! The story was okay, a bit boring for the first half hour, but I was more interested later. There was a serious lack of women, although there were some brief female appearances that I enjoyed. There was an opportunity to see the ladies kick some ass but instead they chose to jump cut to show only the result of the fight, leave the viewer to imagine what happened in between. Hallo, it's an action movie, I want to actually see the fight?! @)#&!

Which brings me to the action in this film, that unfortunately left me very disappointed. To be fair, there were a lot of fights, but I could barely see what was happening! The camera was all over the place during the action scenes. I've seen this happen so often in other films and series that it makes me wonder if they're intentionally trying to hide it because it's not that great. Adding to the mix, close ups in the wrong places, group fights, simultaneous fights going on, it was big mess and I couldn't follow or enjoy any of the choreography.

I can't think of a single fight scene that made feel that adrenaline I remember from movies like Jet Li stepping into a room full of martial artists in Fist of Fury and Kiss of The Dragon, or the first two Transporter movies with Jason Statham, or even the long fight scene in the first Kingsman movie. Or the gun fights in John Wick. How I miss this sort of action, and no one seems to deliver anymore. All I got in this movie is an incomprehensible salad of sword fights I couldn't follow, sigh. Well, if they genuinely tried, I am thankful for the effort, but my craving for action remains.

review_title: Fan of Snake Eyes, not this movie
review_detailed_main: You get garbage when you try to rewrite origin stories.

review_title: Yep. The reviews weren't wrong. Bad!

Even though the screen writing is not good , the massive amount of action could fuel the story and the movie if was R rated . Millions of katana fight sequence and not a single drop of red blood spilled or even seen anywhere !!! Talk about how to kill a movie ! More on that , all the characters are straight on unlovable and not engaging , action sequences are 99% camera movement and techniques rather than actual choreographed fighting. Overall this movie is a waste of time, money and possible a good story that could and mainly the name is ruined.

review_title: This is one those films that is so bad, its good
review_detailed_main: This is one those films that is so bad, its good. The plot is so cheesy, I just can't stop laughing throughout the film.

*Disclaimer there are no spoilers in this review* I don't usually agree with a lot of reviews in movies (mostly the negativity) but I actually agree with the bad reviews on this one. There's is to much confusion that wasn't cleared up in this movie and the lack of storyline. Now I've never read any of the comic books for G. I. joe. But I do know the storyline for snake eyes based off the comic book. The movie did not go by the G. I joe comics what so ever. I've never actually given a negative review. But here are a few ideas of what's wrong with it.

1) It doesn't explain how snake eyes became snake eyes and if you have seen any of the G. I Joe movies there were scenes when snake eyes was younger with storm shadow. So you knew they grew up together But it doesn't explain that or clarify any of that in this movie 2) Storm shadow and Snake eyes relationship is confusing and very hard to understand. Again if you have seen any of the other G. I joe movies you would know they grew up together. In the snake eyes movie it had a whole different point Of view and it made you think "what?" 3) the way snake eyes was trained didn't make any sense and was slow and didn't add up either 4) very slow at first and then towards the end was the "big fight scene." 5) fight scenes where shaky at first which no one likes and was hard to keep track who was fighting who.

For a character that everyone loves like snake eyes. You need to have a strong movie and go off the other G. I joe movies which would only make sense and add up for this snake eyes movie. Advice for anyone who was apart of this movie if you ever are going to make another one don't screw it up.

P. S the actors and actresses did very well though.
Snake Eyes was a awesome movie to see but if you plan on seeing the movie check out my review first before you're it.

review_title: Not great, but not bad either
review_detailed_main: Good action, but also some moments of comedy that wasn't meant to be funny. All in all was an entertaining movie.

This had so much potential.. I like some of the actors and actresses, they have done some great films in the past, but why in heavens name did you pick Schwentke to direct this. He has an appalling record for turning out blockbusters.. and this could have been just that with the right director.

I thought to myself just imagine if the director Keishi Ohtomo had directed this instead. In case you are wondering.. this was the director behind the Rurouni Kenshin film series. But alas it was not to be.
If you love your hard earned money then don't waste it on this movie. You are better off giving the money for the movie ticket to a charity. Terrible movie!

If you have seen one of the G. I Joe movies it goves you a brief history of Snake Eyes. This movie does not use that same history of Snake Eyes as previously told in the g I joe movie and it disappointed me.

The action was great but the producers could have been more accurate with Snake Eyes' history. I would rate it better if it more accurate with previous movies' explanation.

review_title: The new G.I. Joe reboot has a messy beginning.
review_detailed_main:
Snake Eyes G. I. Joe Origins is a reboot of the G. I. Joe movie series. This reboot is directed by Robert Schwentke, the director of RED and R. I. P. D.

In the film, Snake Eyes (Henry Golding) is allowed to join the clan after rescuing the future new leader of the Arashikage clan. Here he gets lessons to become a ninja. During these lessons, Snake Eyes is confronted by his past, causing the clan to question his honor and loyalty. To successfully complete his training, Snake Eyes must regain the clan's trust.

The script and eventual story of the film was written by Evan Spiliotopoulos. He had help from two other writers for this, because he was also busy with his own fan film The Unholy. Because of this pressure, he has finished the script of this film a bit messy.

In addition to the messy script, the film is also filmed somewhat messy. Most action scenes are filmed moving and zoomed in, so as a viewer you don't get a clear picture of what exactly is happening. Other scenes in which characters walk alone are even filmed flexibly, making it almost as if this film was filmed by a director just starting out. For example, the art of Asian martial arts is lost in this film.

The special effects in the film are also not believable. Some creatures show that they were placed in the film with CGI, as well as some flames and explosions. The film is also sometimes a bit too hastily put together where characters move from place to place at a rapid pace. If they had just started the scenes where the characters went, the final movie would have been clearer and shorter.

Despite the lesser script and directing work, Henry Golding tries to make the most of his role. Together with Andrew Koij he does have good chemistry in the film, while with another character he suddenly jumps from a difficult to a passionate relationship. Other characters are in the film more in reference to the G. I. Joe series. Although fans of the G. I. Joe series can recognize the names of some of the characters, they often have to get used to the way they appear in this film.
It's a bit blah ... I really like Henry Golding but I thought he was terrible.

Grow Up Hollywood... Learn How to be creative and actually write new content to put all of your diversity into. Stop changing characters to appease Your agenda. The Most Missed Opportunity is to not change characters that we already know about, but put on your big boy pants and get creative...You want diverse characters... add them to the already existing story-lines in a way that gives us the viewer / reader something to delve into beyond the shallow half-bleeped effort Your machine keeps churning out. I have Nothing against the lead actor in this.. I Hope He goes on to do many great movies, but he was not the correct actor for this. I just don't like the way things are done... Society would rather lower the basketball goal to the ground such that it is like unto golf than expect others to put forth the effort to achieve a goal.... quit watering down content... if You can't be creative then be prepared for the day when another city comes along to steal the show.

Similar to watching a blender being turned on and off for two hours. Just as chaotic, just as loud, and equally boring.

I could handle a thin plot if the action was reasonably exciting, but it was just so lazily staged and generic. A waste of usually good actors.

review_title: Great beginning to a Snake Eyes reboot
review_detailed_main: Y'all apparently don't see the word "Origins" in the title. Going in i figured it would be like the 1st X-men movie with Hugh Jackman as Wolverine. It was. The Snake Eyes character is kinda similar to Wolverine. Pit fighter, trying to find his place in the world, haunted by his past. This reimaging of Snake Eyes is a mix of that along with Han Solo. It's totally different than the Marvel version but I'm fine with it. I loved the action and the arc that the character goes through. It's very much like the 1st X-men where is not a ton of plot but mostly character development and dialog. It's good fun like a Fast and Furious movie. Everyone needs to lighten up and enjoy it.

review_title: Japanese-themed movie with known label slapped on it
review_detailed_main:
On one hand, it is beautiful in every aspect of it! Locations, costume designs, lighting, etc. And almost every action scene is exceptional (with a few exceptions). The sound design was noticeable satisfying, and I have no complaints in regards to the cast. It's very good in general (no bad/annoying roles or deliveries). Although some are underused, and their response to movie-situations is questionable at times.

Sadly, this is a very bland movie.. and as a G. I. Joe movie it is even worse! More so for the character of Snake Eyes (has to be seen to be understood, and a little investment on the character is required). This is because I didn't particularly enjoy the role given to the main lead and his development is undercooked. The story itself is nothing new (even with the addition of certain details). A configuration of things we've seen before many times making it not only predictable and a tad forgettable. And all in the service of a conclusion that is nothing short of a disappointment..

It's no wonder word of mouth didn't help, but it can still be watched. And I'll lower my expectations for the sequel, if it ever comes.

This movie really sucked both as an origin story and an action flick based on a once-famous toyline. The writing is so damn bland that you won't care for a single character. Samara Weaving's there in a blink & miss role, and she's the only one in this mess who commands decent screen presence. The less about the main cast, the better. Henry Golding looks uncomfortable in the role of Snake Eyes and struggles to carry it all the way. I did like Andrew Koji's portrayal of Storm Shadow to an extent. The plotting is, however, the worst. How can you stage a ninja clan feud so terribly? Badly shot (too much shaky cam) and weirdly edited, the action scenes are not what you'd want from a G. I Joe movie. I thought this would make for a great popcorn actioner, but what I watched turned out to be one of the trashiest films of the year.

review_title: Very badly handling of the subject matter.
review_detailed_main:
Snake Eyes is a movie that simply fails to make use of what it's given.

The movie is too violent to really be a kid's movie, yet the plot it poorly written, shallow and predictable, and full of holes, so it doesn't work as a movie for adults either. It's like they couldn't decide if they wanted to make a movie for the kids who like the newer GI Joe shows, or the adults who grew up with the originals, and simply failed to live up to either.

The story is just bad. Honestly the original cartoon had more elaborate and well thought out plotlines. This was just cliche as hell and so by the numbers it's painful. The writing is terrible. No real banter, no real emotion beyond the ham fisted stuff they put in to try and give characters some sort of drive, but it just makes them feel horribly artificial. A lot of the decisions characters make are completely nonsensical. And there's just no real flow.

There's also a great deal of blunders, plot holes, and just mistakes made throughout. Things that make no sense. Not to mention the insanely annoying cliche of the guy who's trained for a month somehow being better than people who have dedicated themselves for years. So tiring to see characters pick up a weapon and suddenly being an unstoppable god.

The combat scenes are terrible. Just full of endless jump cuts so they're a chaotic mess with no real impact. Not only jumping between views of the characters but also jumping between different fights. It's painful trying to keep track of who's fighting who and just what's going on. When will directors learn to use actual choreographed fight scenes instead of a hundred 2 second pieces?

The special effects were lackluster. Nothing big was needed, but even what little they had just felt like an afterthought.

If you want to know how he becomes capbable of being a deadly fighter and ninja, you will get nothing of the sort here. In the first scene we first see him as a young boy, then the movie fast forwards to him as an adult fighting in a cage. He's already a tough guy and knows how to fight and wins the match. Next action scene he's fighting ten guys at once. When he's given a sword, he already knows how to to use it like an expert. There is some physical training he gets later on, but it's all very brief with no sense of progression or accomplishment. He knows already how to do everything.

For an action movie, it's mediocre at best. It barely held my interest after the halfway point and the tie in with the GJ Joe and Cobra characters was clunky and in some scenes (with Scarlet or the Baroness) almost cringey.

review_title: Charismatic martial arts action film with stunning choreographies, locations and acting
review_detailed_main:
I'm usually neither fond of superhero movies in general nor of the Marvel franchise in particular but Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins is a very positive exception for me and a movie that is much better than its lukewarm reception might indicate.

First and foremost, this film is a feast of martial arts fans. Back in the seventies, there were four new martial arts films at the cinema every week but these days they are hard to come by. In this film, we see ferocious fist fights but also the use of daggers, pistols and swords and even some elements of magic. The choreography is stunning and the pace is at times breathtaking.

Up next, the locations for this movie have been chosen with care. The film starts with a series of different locations from a cabin in the woods over a shady underground fighting circuit to a port infiltrated with criminals. Most of the movie however takes place in a Japanese ninja dojo that looks absolutely stunning. This starts with the traditional buildings and continues with the surrounding forests, gardens, temples and shrines. The settings are very detailed and ooze with atmosphere.

The acting performances are also very decent. It was a great pleasure to see Iko Uwais on the big screen again but he doesn't play a ferocious martial artist but rather a wise teacher in this film which suits him surprisingly well. The same could be said about Peter Mensah as a blind master whose words are filled with philosophy and wisdom. My personal highlight is however Abe Haruka who appears as an analytical security boss at first but turns out to be an empathic, foresightful and intelligent woman.

The story is also very interesting as it offers many twists and turns and makes viewers ask themselves how they would react under similar circumstances. If I were on a quest to avenge my family but were invited as a friend to a ninja dojo controlled by such a charismatic security boss, I would probably not pursue the path of betrayal.

At the end of the day, Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins is much better than its reputation and turns out to be a charismatic martial arts action film that should appeal to a much larger audience than those who are only interested in superhero movies.

The script rolled snake eyes, and the studio responsible for this losing bet decided to double down on the idea and produce this garbage. The only thing that kept me watching this failure to the end was Haruka Abe.

A Kick from the hip and a Kick to the curb This movie does not have a "Go Joe Moment " and that is a shame, I expected more out of this Origin story of one of the favorite characters in the GI Joe world. The dialog was too low, the action scenes were way too loud, the fights and sword play were choppy and the story was not up to snuff.

review_title: Snake-Eyes Makes Michael Bay's Transformers Look Like Citizen Kane
review_detailed_main:
How hard could it be to make a Snake-Eyes movie? He is the epitome of the cool, quiet ninja. He has a great origin story as depicted in 30 years worth of comics and cartoons. Reboot it, fine, but just do that. You have a wealth of source material. Seriously, how hard could it be? As this movie shows you, pretty darn hard.

I am baffled how the team that made this movie could get everything wrong. They assemble a cast that can throw down and fight and the fight scenes are literally seconds long, mostly in the dark, with extremely quick cuts. The acting is sub-par but, to be fair, they weren't given much to work with. I think other reviewers are giving Andrew Koji a pass because of Warrior but he is super cheesy in the role of Storm Shadow. His performance is full of a forced, hammy earnestness as he delivers lines from a comic book movie that sounds like they were written by and for eight year olds. And speaking of eight year olds, one of the "veteran" screenwriters is a veteran of working on terrible Disney sequels like Cinderella 3, Tarzan 2 and Jungle Book 2. Oh, and he wrote 2 Pooh Heffalump movies. He DOES write for eight year olds and it shows here. The story is beyond juvenile and shows little understanding of what is great or interesting about the source material. Even the fan service is completely misplaced here. There is a scene late in the movie where Snake-Eyes walks up to Scarlett right before one of the climactic (non) fight scenes and casually says, "Yo, Joe." But this is an ORIGIN movie and he barely even knows what G. I. Joe is at this point. How would he know to say that? I think the screenwriters were so inept at their craft that they thought they could take a movie about a ninja named Snake-Eyes and build it around a literal pair of dice that only rolls ones and three literal snakes. Anacondas. Not even Cobras.

This whole thing is a hot mess. And not even an interesting mess. A super bland and generic boring mess. It's Snake-Eyes. How do you do that? Thank God this movie tanked so bad that we will probably not be subjected to any more of this nonsense and Larry Hama won't have to pretend that he likes it.

I don't know why I was even expecting this to be good. Wishful thinking I suppose because I loved watching Snake Eyes in GI Joe. However, this movie just seemed to make no sense and was all over the place. Of course they added the guy from the warrior show, who tried to look way to cool like everyone else and came off pretty shallow and uninteresting. I'll be honest I couldn't even finish it, only watched a little over an hour.

review_title: way to ruin a awesome franchise

review_detailed_main:
I actually liked the two first G. I. Joe movies, G. I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra and G. I. Joe: Retaliation. This one... not so much.

It could have been a really good movie but it ended up as a huge disappointment. The story should have been a cool revenge story but it ended up being a convoluted mess making Snake Eyes one of the bad guys for most of the movie. It is also hugely predictable after the first 20 minutes of the movie. Did the writers really think that the "twists" would come as a surprise for anyone? They probably did since Hollywod writers usually reside on the low end of the intelligence scale nowadays. Putting three of those hacks together to write a movie doesn't help of course.

I could have accepted all of that if the rest would have been cool with lots of fights and special effects. Sadly the movie is mediocre, at best, in these areas as well.

Snake Eyes is not only a bad guy but he is rather stupid as well as devoid of any charisma. His acting is quite poor which can be said for most of the actors actually. Apart from the mediocre acting there's really no one in the movie that you feel like rooting for. No one stands out, everyone just excels in mediocrity. The only person in the entire movie that has any coolness factor worth talking about is Scarlett but she is not in the movie for more than a few scenes.

There are a few scenes with some special effects, cars flipping over, huge snakes etc. But not really that much for this kind of movie. That could have been fine since this movie should be a lot about martial arts. Amazingly enough, not even here does it deliver. Most of the martial arts scenes involve a lot of flipping around with arms and swords but they mostly look like they have been written for a PG rated TV show for teens and pre-teens. They are simply poor. Tommy looks like he needs to take a dump before every fight with that ridiculous pose of his.

This is not a 1-star movie as some rate it. That's just ridiculous. It has some entertainment value. However, it could have been so much better. Unfortunately I suspect this movie has done the G. I. Joe franchise a disservice for some time to come.
It would have been better if they had stuck to the comics. This adaptation was simply another ninja movie with a sub-par plot line and even worse dialogue. Don't watch. You will be wasting your life.
