review_title: The new origin of Snake Eyes and the reboot of the franchise
review_detailed_main: The G. I. movies Joe apparently didn't have as much of an impact as the movies in the Transformers franchise. So starting again from scratch, we have this spinoff focused on the origin of Snake Eyes that reboots the saga of G. I. Joe, as the origin story seen here about how the feud between Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow came to be is not the same as the one seen in the Rise Of Cobra flashbacks. Without forgetting to mention that both these two characters and The Baroness and Scarlett O'Hara are played by other actors. This origin story is well written in the style of classic martial arts action movies and this movie manages to fit that category very well. You can see the evolution of Snake Eyes being at the beginning someone who is willing to do anything to avenge the death of his father. The friendship that he develops with Storm Shadow at the beginning and how he ends up getting lost is also well captured. Akiko is also well developed as the voice of reason who is suspicious of Snake Eyes being aware of the risk that she is present, but later bonding with him. The script offers a very good story in the pure anime style, with a good balance between the action, the evolution of Snake Eyes as a person and his internal conflict about whether to do whatever it takes to get revenge on him no matter the cost. As a martial arts action movie it's great and works very well. Unfortunately, it does not have the support it deserves. Of course it is a very different origin story, but since this is a reboot, this new story is valid, since the origin of the rivalry between Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow has varied according to the different installments of the franchise that present different versions of the G. I. Joe, although maintaining certain characteristics. The reality is, you don't need to know all the G. I. Joe or be 100 percent faithful to the source material because each installment has its own version of the story. In addition, it is very evident that even though some claim to be loyal fans or specialized critics, it is very clear that they do not have the capacity to give a film the value it really deserves and that makes their arguments invalid. So all in all, Snake Eyes is actually a good movie that those with low IQs don't know how to appreciate. Since the live action Transformers has been split into 2 universes since Bumblebee came out, it's totally valid that this movie wanted to use the same formula. Therefore, this movie presents an alternate universe of G. I. Joe that it can be better or be at the level of the two previous films. After all, in the multiverse of Hasbro-created franchises, anything goes. My final rating for this movie is 9/10.

review_title: Story makes me feel like they think viewers are all stupid
Despite focusing on one of the franchises most popular characters, Snake Eyes: G.I. Joe Origins is a rather dull ride.
review_detailed_main:
Following witnessing the death of his father twenty years ago, a man known only as "Snake Eyes" (Henry Golding) lives as a drifter who makes his way through underground fighting. Snake Eyes is approached by Yakuza boss, Kenta Takamura (Takehiro Hira), approaches Snake Eyes and makes an offer that he will give him his father's murderer in exchange for working for him. Some time later Snake Eyes is working for Kenta's gun smuggling ring, until one of Kenta's underlings, Tomisaburo "Tommy" Arashikage (Andrew Koji) is revealed to actually be Kenta's cousin who's been trying to stop Kenta's illegal activities. When Snake Eyes disobeys an order to kill Tommy, the two escape to Japan where Tommy introduces Snake Eyes to his clan of Ninja and offers him a place there, much to the objection of the clan's head of security, Akiko (Haruka Abe). Now Snake Eyes must pass three trials from the clans mentors Hard Master (Iko Uwais) and Blind Master (Peter Mensah), while also navigating a convoluted web involving the Arashikage Clan, Cobra, and members of G. I. Joe with Snake Eyes caught in the middle.

Paramount since 2007 has had a lucrative partnership with toy company, Hasbro, with their initial adaptation of Transformers in 2007 getting the ball rolling on not only 5 follow-up films in that series, but also in adapting other well known legacy properties ranging from board games like Ouija and Battleship to other 80s toy properties like M. A. S. K. and Micronauts. A close second to Transformers in terms of popularity is the G. I. Joe with trying to jump start a film series in 2009 with G. I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra. The Rise of Cobra while not a bomb, didn't pull in the Transformers levels of money the studio was expecting, leading to the "soft reboot" G. I. Joe: Retaliation which was beset by production problems and reshoots (particularly involving regret at killing off Channing Tatum's character fulling the actors surge in popularity with Magic Mike and 21 Jump Street) and again lead to "okay" returns at the box office, but still well short of Transformers money. Despite the mixed reception of those movies, the one element that was pretty universally liked was in the film's handling of the character Snake Eyes as played by Ray Park. Like the cartoon and comic book, Snake Eyes doesn't talk and most of his personality comes from his body language and mystique and the films did a good job incorporating him as part of an ensemble and giving resonance to his long standing feud with Storm Shadow. When Paramount announced a spin-off of this character who doesn't speak, I'll admit I had reservations, but with Bumblebee managing to exceed my expectations I was willing to give it a chance. Snake Eyes: G. I. Joe Origins is unfortunately a step backwards for this series that wasn't exactly firing on all cylinders to begin with.

Henry Golding does fine in his first outing headlining a major action film, as he's a charismatic presence with charm and likability, but I had a hard time buying him as Snake Eyes. I don't think this is Golding's fault per se, and I'm not opposed to having Snake Eyes talk in an origin story, but at no point did I feel like the character we were seeing was Snake Eyes. The movie at it's core plays like a mixture of an 80s Ninja movie crossed with one of those noir movies where a westerner goes to explore Japan's criminal underworld (The Yakuza, The Challenge, etc.) only without the cheesy fun of the former or the craft and gravitas of the latter. Most of the film's characters are played like stiffs with very little in the way of energy or drive. I did enjoy the performances by the underutilized Iko Uwais and Peter Mensah as Hard Master and Blind Master respectively, and honestly would've liked to see more of them in the movie training Snake Eyes. The movie does come to life when it gets a bit sillier in its final act with Cobra's Baroness and G. I. Joe's Scarlett played by Ursula Corbero and Samara Weaving respectively, but there presence is so jarring in comparison to the deliberately paced and stoic first 3/4ths of the movie by the final act it barely feels like we're even in the same film as when we started.

Snake Eyes is unfortunately a boring take on the popular G. I. Joe character. Despite Henry Golding doing his best to light up his performance, he's dragged down by a bloated convoluted script that doesn't carry enough weight with its characters to resonate. The action is serviceable, but with a two hour run time carry a messy plot and confused character motivations I found myself checking the time and getting antsy by he 1 hour mark.

"I can't change your past, but I can offer you a purpose" - Tommy Tommy's clan is the ancient Japanese Arashikage Family. review_title: Good...the beginning of the end of Lorenzo Di Bonaventura's career (hopefully)

....at least with GI:Joe. Three big multi-million blockbuster attempts to make one decent GI : Joe film - I mean really...clearly he has NO tability in making quality films. This film, most likely - as others speculate - was probably made in a hurry to retain the rights of the franchise which he should just let go of.

Sure, he can get some bums on seats with good marketing - but he makes AWFUL films and this is another he can add to the list. Just give it up and let some younger, talented producers/film-makers take the reins from now.

I say this because I have been an extra on several of his productions including this one in one of the opening scenes - the atmosphere was horrible and no one was happy. The actors and crew were doing their best - most of the fighting I saw must have ended up on the cutting room floor because I saw none of it in the final product. It was actually quite dangerous for people doing the action and it wasn't even worth if unfortunately. Other sets I work on are so much better in almost every way. I would say steer clear of this man's films

As for the film itself - the cast do a good job - I can never buy Henry Golding as an action tough guy - he's too soft and certainly not my Snake eyes - I remember his double was used a lot too - which is probably why they needed to cut a lot I guess. The writing is awful and plot holes galore - how mature decision making adults could have read the script and thought it was a good idea to go ahead with is beyond me. People are speculating Golding was a replacement for Charlie Hunman who would have been way better.

This film had the possibility of being good but with terrible decision makers up top - it'll never happen and they'll waste so much money and lead so many people on with false advertising - it needs to stop.

The fact Iko Uwais was in this crap, is so disappointing. He is a legend in our house. To use him in this tosh is just not right. He deserves so much better.

2/10.

Snake Eyes Review I don't know why they went with "GI Joe origins. Don't they know how that turned out for X-men? Probably won't go better for them. Between the nauseating shaky cam, Henry Golding's inconsistent accent, and the ham-fisted naming, it was a far cry from masterpiece. In the case of the naming, it didn't even make sense in the case of Snake Eyes; he was taking his name from a random statement made by the man who killed his father. Couple that with the VERY half-baked universe tie-in, and a contradiction of their own lore, and you have a movie that's ok go to downright meh. Worst of all (for me) is that, by the end of the movie, there was no vow of silence.

On the other hand, there were some things that were great about the movie. The costume design on POINT (shoutout to Louise Mingenbach). There were good fights, but Iko Iwais was CRIMINALLY underused. Also, the movie had excellent set pieces.

All in all, a solid 6 on its own, 5 as a GI Joe prequel.

The singular actor with any sort of gravitas in this film, and the only positive element

and what's with the magical fantastical elements in a guns&tanks action franchise, and the writers not even adding in 1 casualty of 1 side character of the 'good' or 'evil' side? Well, it can be argued that this reflects the movie's roots of a kids cartoon where the good guys always win, and the bad guys always loses but always comes back a few episode later.

The protrayed purity and moral perfection of these 'good guys' (a test is featured prominently in defining this attribute) and their mirrored 'absolute evil' Yakuza and Cobra feels extemely out of place in a world setting that is based on today's reality.

They really should had gone full cartoon for the world-building as well, rather than leaving it half-and-half.

On brawls, only split seconds snapshots of potentially exciting action. Unfortunate.

On set pieces, they couldn't come up with anything better than a knockoff copy of Matrix's 2 highway action scene (other than an obvious CGI background on a countryside highway)

Oh, and the clan also have some of the lamest rules ever written in any film. No wonder their boy-wonder was pissed.

Don't get me wrong, it wasn't that engaging before that point. But the first 20 minutes were actually ok, all the Yakuza port stuff was pretty good if not for the shaky cam.

While watching it, I felt like I was trying to like it more than I should. It was almost like it was trying to get good, but never quite reached that point.

There are lots of weird things going on in this production in general. First of all - Robert Schwentke. The name rang a bell so I checked and yes - I've seen Der Hauptmann. Why Snake Eyes? I don't know, maybe it's the paycheck. Then there are weird tonal jumps, serious and gritty (but basic) mob-revenge plot mixed with magic giant anacondas (and flying grandmas). I understand the simplicity of the source material, but why make it as serious at times? Kids won't enjoy it since the actions scenes are mostly short and shot with shaky cam. Adults are never going to take this story seriously, especially after the clownery of the past 90-minute mark. After the magical reunion, it just became a complete farce.

I think that this film was salvaged by all the talented people that were in it. Andrew Koji was a saving grace of this film, I liked his acting a lot. Then there's Iko Uwais, but they mostly wasted his skills since we barely see him doing anything. The CGI was surprisingly good for such a film also.

Snake Eyes is extremely unlikable and gives you no reason to root for him. Maybe this was intentional, but his ark never feels accomplished.

The film had a couple of nice sets, although I'd wish they would have all the Japanese scenery set in wintertime, that would've been great. Also, I had a feeling that the film was set in the 90ties but when it came to product placement it suddenly switched to modern-day cars, embarrassing.

I didn't like any of the other cast besides Takehiro Hira as Kenta. Baroness was a joke, Scarlett's presence in the film wasn't justified at all, just have more giant anacondas instead.

Overall, I can't say I expected anything at all, and there was no reason for the film to exist. It's not like there is a demand for G. I. Joe origins whatever-verse. In the end, I just feel sad about the talent of the film. Hope everyone was well-paid for this.

I've seen B movies with a better plot than this one, American Ninja for example. Where did he learn to fight with a sword ? So much non sense and illogical premises is not worth my time mentioning. Are people becoming this dull to pay to see this kind of crap ? Well then, I guess we deserve it.

The cast, the costumes, the setting! To me, in my opinion (despite the few plot holes here and there) was already detailed enough. The action sequence was good. And the CGI, wow! You should see it for yourself when you get to watch that part. I rather be careful reviewing this because I don't really want to give away any spoilers. So forgive me if I wouldn't put much detail. I can only say that I went to the cinema not expecting so much, but in the end, I actually enjoyed it! So I recommend to give this movie a chance and watch it!

review_title: Movie Box--for the last 2 was Shows movie cover with no way to watch =-(
review_detailed_main: My app shows COVER FOR THE movie only, No link to watch. Been like that for almost 2 weeks. .How can I really rate if I can't watch it =-(. THE TRAILER LOOKS GREAT THOUGH. Been waiting to watch. =-(

review_title: Wonderful costumes, weak characters, lazy plot, boring action
review_detailed_main:
One of the main characters has a scar on his face, that changes color, length and location with every scene.

The main hero has a moral compass of a toddler and can't tell good from bad at a level that makes it impossible to respect or like him.

A strong woman character got treated as a prop.

All of a sudden Harry Potter magic stuff from movies 1 and 2 pops in.



+ Sets, light and costumes are beautiful and captivating.

review_title: Even as a re-skinned script it still fails...
review_detailed_main:
I can't help but feel like this movie was a different script originally and the G. I. Joe stuff got tagged on. While pretending you're not watching a movie about THE Snake Eyes from G. I. Joe makes the movie a little more tolerable, it's still not that great of a movie. The people that are supposed to end up as the bad guys are almost the good guys while the good guy is basically a bad guy. As I said, they must have taken a script, and applied a G. I. Joe label on it.

That said, the only reason to watch this movie is to see a cool action movie, and even then it falls short. People draw swords and start kicking one another. People with guns run up to try and shoot someone point-blank only to have the gun knocked away as they get punched. People can jump off moving vehicles, over other moving vehicles, and land on yet another moving vehicle. There's the suspension of disbelief and then there's just magic now because the director says so. This movie also makes joining a ninja clan look as easy as signing up at your local dojo.

Not really much to be excited about with this movie. They completely changed the origin story of Snake Eyes & not for the better. It really just bounced around too much for my liking, the storyline was inconsistent and the acting was "wooden". Just was not impressed at all with it, I was certainly expecting a lot more. Disappointing...

review_title: Why the change in the background story?!
review_detailed_main:
Very bad movie. Missed all the background story shown in the GJ Joe movies, they didn't even mention the vow of silence! In the movie it shows that they grew up as kids and got separated after their master was killed.

The movie is disgusting.

I loved the ingredients that went into this movie even though the end result could've been better. The actors were great, the costumes and visuals outstanding. The shaky cam thing should die a horrible death because the people who did the action WOULD'VE looked better in static wide shots but they were robbed of the chance to show their talents.

I give it 10/10 solely for the potential that it has because Andrew Koji is not just a fighter and Harry Golding is not just a pretty face - they have incredible chemistry and given a good script they can deliver top tier dramatic performances that will stay with you after you leave the movie theater. And one thing that was good despite any logical expectation is that they made both characters completely OOC but somehow it worked exactly the same way as in the original story because you can FEEL the heartwrenching potential of what could've been. It just works.

review_title: Potential wasted by some major issues.
review_detailed_main:
I will keep this short, this is an action film and the action isn't good enough, the choreography is poor and the action lacks imagination. Snake Eyes, who we love for just straight up kicking ass, is portrayed as a bumbling buffoon or 3rd fiddle for the majority of the film. Most of the other characters are far more intelligent and skilled than he is unfortunately. I know this is an origin film so is he suppose to be learning but he underpowered majorly. The whole story had potential but it was too messy and directionless.

This actually had quality production, a decent script and acting (surprisingly). The cinematography was good to there was some interests sets and shots.

I enjoyed Henry Golding and Andrew Koji as the leads.

But for me the action/choreography and story wasn't good enough.

5/10.
The only reason why I have given two stars is that it was a slow Sunday... and I had nothing else to see... horribly lame....
This is one of the worst movies I watched in along time. Poor Acting,terrible story line.

review_title: I left the theater dumber than when I entered
review_detailed_main: I only sat through the whole movie because I was with friends. I haven't experienced cinema that painful since Cabin Boy (1994).

review_title: From a true GI Joe fan, I loved it!!

review_detailed_main: If we take away the other GI Joe movies this movie has a decent story but since they keep changing and re writing these movies ot just takes away the enjoyment. The continuity in movies is is getting out of control but that's another point. Here comes snake eyes, by far one, if not the most popular action figures from a lot of our childhoods. Where the other two GI Joe movies got it right playing to the childhood imagination this one is much more darker. The story itself was decent bit then the fighting scenes where just a hog pop of close ups that just looked lazy. The acting was pretty good individually bit they lacked the chemistry. I'm a nerd so I had to see it in theaters but just wait for a streaming service.

review_title: Bad story. Bad casting. Bad acting. Bad action. Just bad.
review_detailed_main:
Mangled the Snake Eyes character and his origin story as found in the comics.

This is not Snake Eyes.

This is not Storm Shadow.

This is not Cobra.

This is not G. I. Joe.

This movie is not even a good action movie with bad casting, bad action scenes, bad acting, and a very very bad storyline.

review_title: Everything that is wrong with movies today
review_detailed_main:
Bad writing, "cinematic universe" instead of actual character arcs, shaky cam, disgusting high contrast eye cancer color grading with crushed blacks like it's 2004, more shaky cam, poorly edited fight scenes with cuts on impact, yellow tint on everything that makes everyone look like they have jaundice (or hail from Springfield), martial arts fight atop speeding CGI vehicles during a chase scene, Katanas and black leather like it's the Matrix, laughably bad CGI and cartoon physics fight scenes, and actors trying really really hard to be dramatic and not having fun with their role.

Terrible.

review_title: Enjoyable Movie, Great Action Scenes! Classic GI Joe Franchise.
review_detailed_main:
This movie was enjoyable. Not perfect, but I think it deserves more credit. It would have been something that I would have really enjoyed as a kid in the 90's (I was a big GI Joe fan as a kid, but it was so long ago, I barely remembered it). The movie's strong points are its action sequences, the good looking filming locations and set, and the Japanese culture inside the film. The casting was great, the actors did a good job (and many of them are pretty good looking as well). I really enjoyed the underground Japanese theme and scenery, the streets of Japan mixed with traditional Japanese towns. I think the storyline and script could have been a little better, and there were a couple of oddities in the film which I thought were very weird and the film didn't really explain it (but I understood they had limited time for a movie, I'm sure there's a lot of deleted and extra scenes). The lead actor, Henry Golding, did a great job; he is always enjoyable to watch on the screen.

I think many hardcore retro and comic enthusiasts are mad that the lead character is not white like how it was originally supposed to be in the original franchise, but I don't think they realize that Henry Golding is half white and has a white father in real life (though Henry Golding does look more Asian). I'm actually glad they casted an Asian lead character, I felt that it worked out very well with the casting and I can't imagine it being someone else. Many films in the past like Dragon Ball Z, Avatar: The Last Air Bender, and Ghost in the Shell live action films all had white lead actors, many Asian people felt very upset about all of these films that cast a white character in place for an Asian character, and the lack of Asian lead characters in mainstream western films. The only issue is the script and storyline which could have used improvement (which I mentioned earlier). But the overall film, especially the action sequences, was very good and enjoyable. I think people sometimes get way too into movies and critique and nitpick every single small thing about the film, but at the end of the day, a movie is entertainment and I was definitely entertained well enough. To be fair, this movie was way better than the last two GI Joe films which were disappointing, so I think they did a much better job this time with this origin story film. There are many films that get very user review high ratings but I didn't really like those films that much, and there are films that had low review ratings but I ended up enjoying it and thought it was decent. So film reviewers have their biases, I rate based on entertainment value.

If they were clever enough, they'd have given the lead role to Andrew Koji from Warrior! The lead they have just doesn't lead well and this shows, never-mind the balance of the actors! This was a feeble attempt at reigniting this franchise, CGI was even worse than the script! Not worth the watch and hype TBH!

review_title: A shambolic origin story for a beloved GI Joe character!
review_detailed_main:
The GI Joe franchise has been moderately successful due to its over-the-top, Fast & Furious style action sequences and not over any great depth in screenplay. Director Robert Schwentke seems to have forgotten this, delivering a half-baked product in 'Snake Eyes', the origin story of one of the most beloved GI Joe characters.

Henry Golding stars as the iconic Ninja warrior and we catch him right from his tumultuous childhood as he grows up on the streets after losing his dad. Andrew Koji is fantastic is his arch nemesis 'Storm Shadow' and we see how they go from blood brothers to arch enemies.

The usually dependable Úrsula Corberó (Tokyo from Money Heist) was given precious little to work with in a villainous role, with the writing wearing this on too many occasions. With cliches twists and repetitive action sequences that fail to wow you, 'Snake Eyes' reduces to a tiring watch.

With the wide canvas of a fresh GI Joe origin story open to him, it is criminal that the director wasn't able to paint a better picture of the beloved children's toy series. Samara Weaving is abysmal as the Joe agent 'Scarlett' and Takehiro Hira is more comical than menacing as the diabolical 'Kenta'.

A big let down, especially given how much of a fan following this character has. Not recommended!

A complete letdown from the GI Joe franchise. Very dragging movie and very poor script writing. It's also not the story I expected because from GI Joe Retaliation, Snake eyes and Storm shadow grew up together. The Arashikage ninja is the cornerstone of Japan but they looked like a completely useless ninjas when Snake eyes broke into their palace alone. All in all, I want to unwatch this movie.

...kingly thought this film was about the first ever elite military secret quad, but it's one of its member's origin story instead! I'm an unfortunate relic of the 80's toy craze: Matchbox, Lego, Dolls 4 boys called Action Figures usually by Hasbro, and roller skates! The more you had didn't matter unless it was with the most recent release. When Star Wars figurines finally landed in the big supermarkets in the 'burbs, after a long stint in select hobby shops usually in the City Centre, the craze peaked!

The G. I. Joe's were what you'd take to school, but not just for show and tell! If you lost at marbles you could bet your figure, and those stakes couldn't be higher...for a 10 year old!

So when the first G. I. Joe films fizzled through theatres, I was a bit less disappointed than Star Wars Episode I, which is still pretty peeved! My G. I. Joe was never so...blah!

But Snake Eyes, the hardest toy to find, as a film hit my high mark! Shallow storyline pales with the amazing swordplay and martial arts on offer.

Henry sells the part, and finally warms your heart as he grows and learns. For a journey that takes a villian and transforms him into an unsung hero, this one ticks all the boxes.

Populated by unknown actors for the mainstream western viewers, but not for Asian film buffs, a handful of familiar faces spruce up the assemble cast. Notably, Tokyo from the Netflix smash hit Casa De Papel (Money Heist) ironically shows up when Snake/Henry goes to Japan's capital city of the same name! Even her English surprised and amused me after her gorgeous Spanish! But I digress!

Snake Eyes contains the basic, well known fundamental morals that prop up the ninja folklore. Namely trust, honour, honesty, and heritage, heritage, heritage! These were no cheap mercenaries like the secret US government's organisation used to Control Chaos. Or vice versa! Snake has to infiltrate this close-knit army of deadly acrobats for nefarious reasons we learn as we follow him.

Motorcycle chases that will leave your knees shaking and your knuckles white, bookended by a choreographed cartop freeway fight scene that would rival Matrix Reloaded's and you've got yourself a pretty good entry into the rebooted franchise! Let's hope future instalments stear less towards Avengers and more to the ninja-honest cartoons' origins!

I loved the culturally appropriate representation (not a white ninja in sight)!

It made me want to go back and watch the less appealing ones!

review_title: Horrible and worst screenplay of the year
review_detailed_main: This movie I thought was gonna be good action packed and good plot NOOO boring slow paced and not even feels like a GI Joe film!! But this movie would be perfect for 5 year olds with no brain!! LOL.

Zero logic.

Zero story line.

Laughed more at the absurdity of everything.

Should be classified as a comedy.

review_title: Action is good, but it broke the franchise
Not a genuine Snake eyes Origin story
review_detailed_main: This story line and "origins" is a complete fabrication by some writer that decided to make up his/her own story line and origin. Nearly none of the story and plot stays within any canon in the Gi Joe Universe, either Hasbro, or Marvel. Rise of Cobra already did an Origins story that was somewhat more consistent with canon and 100% better than this junk. It's almost embarrassing to even call this a Gi Joe Origin story of Snake eyes. Total junk.

Am I the only one that thought this was waaaaaay better than the 2 other GI Joe movies?

I felt it was refreshing in compariskn to the 2 other ones. Those made me feel like I was treated like a moron.

Yes the story is kinda... tacky but I watched this out of nostalgia and the fact that I wanted good action.

I got what I wanted.

Suberb filming locations truly set the atmosphere right. I was impressed because you get immersed in another world.

Let's hope Snake Eyes get's a well deserved sequel.

Aside from the main Japanese cast, it seems like they were going for over the top, cliched actors/actresses delivering terrible lines. The locations were amazing. The plot seemed decent but quickly fell apart after about the halfway point. The action scenes involving the motorcycles had promise, but not only were they physics defying, but even 3rd grader logic defying. Now, if you enjoy straight up sword fights, this is possibly worth watching. Otherwise don't tarnish those childhood memories.

...terrible origin story. The writing was terrible as far as Snake Eyes's decisions in this movie. The action sequences were awful, as everyone else has said about the shaky camera angles. So much potential to be an amazing origin story, ruined by simply awful writing.

I thought the introduction of GI Joe and Cpbra was clunky at best, and the characters of Scarlet and Baroness were flat and boring. Tommy and Snake's relationship should have been much more developed, and the "does she or doesn't she love Snake" angle with Akiko was superfluous.

If they are intending on rebooting GI Joe, I hope this isn't canon.

review_title: We are building a force of Extwordinary magnitude.
review_detailed_main:
This just felt like an underfunded, tinny, badly choreographed, poorly acted 1970 Kung Foo film.

Kentucky Fried Movie did it more realistically and better.

review_title: Nowhere near as good as the previous G.I Joe movies.
review_detailed_main:
I like G. I joe: The Rise Of Cobra and G. I Joe: Retaliation, they are fun over the top action movies with pretty great action scenes and good casts. They're basically live action cartoons and even though they are PG-13 rated movies the action is still pretty visceral and exciting. The filmmakers know what kind of movies they are and they run with it.

Snake Eyes is a reboot of the series and i was pretty excited to see it but in the end i thought it was shallow and actually pretty boring. The tone of the movie is a lot more serious this time around but this just makes it unintentionally funny in places and the action is really messy and tame.

I mean it features Iko Uwais from The Raid who is an immensely skilled martial artist but the movie barely lets him do anything and so many times during the action scenes just as it's about to get cool the camera cuts away to something else. This is lame as hell.

It's supposed to be the origin story of a G. I Joe character but the whole G. I Joe element seems like it's shoehorned in. If it wasn't there the movie wouldn't be any different.

Also Henry Golding keeps forgetting his American accent, so many times he just flat out speaks in an English accent and i was like "Oh! Plot twist!".

review_title: This is best for action movie lover 😍
review_detailed_main:
This movie is very nice for watching one time The story of this movie is average, but the action is very good.

I think its part two will come and I will wait Now you decide,whether you want to watch a movie or not .

review_title: There was nothing wrong with the back story of Snake Eyes in the comic books...
How can you get this so wrong
review_detailed_main: Growing up reading G. I. Jow comics, watching the cartoon, having the toys I was hoping for a real accurate telling of the real origin of Snake Eyes. Well, I was really wrong. How can Hasbro with ALL the material, legacy, and style of the story of Snake Eyes could they get this so wrong.
This movie was honestly pretty boring although my expectations weren't super high There's not much character development and I was disappointed when snake eyes didn't even where his signature suit.👎
In the G. I joe's moves snake eyes was something else Better than this movie.

It was so boring! So boring that i played 3 rounds of COD battle royale in between! Checked my Instagram constantly and posted some stories, yet i still knew what would happen at the end.

Unnecessary addition to the franchise. Not even fun as an action movie, all action scenes were B rated! Stupid and bland.

Heroes fighting guns with swords , giant stupid cgi snakes , fires coming out of ground.. I yawned so much my jaws ache!

Gave it 1 star just because I couldn't give a 0.

review_title: Get a decent director, good cast and have a terrible script
review_detailed_main: So the director who brought us the fun film Red and a good cast are subjected to an awful storyline and script. To give it context the 'scriptwriters' previous works are - Pooh's Heffalump Movie, Race and Seberg plus other Disney straight to video and romance films a plenty. So you have to wonder why hire these people to reboot a franchise like G. I. Joe, there is no logic?

review_title: The biggest problem with it is that it's just plain boring.
review_detailed_main: It so desperately wants to be the ninja Marvel movie that it fails to understand what draws people to either martial arts or Marvel films. While watchable, it's entirely forgettable - a wall of noise and motion that would only be convincingly entertaining as background noise, since at least then you could fill in the gaps with the more interesting version in your imagination.
Origin stories for action heroes are all the rage, but without a real story to tell it's just one big fight scene pieced together by bad plot. Such is the case with this one, unfortunately.

review_title: One of the worst movies I've seen
review_detailed_main:
This is one of the worst movies I've seen (along with Wonder Woman 1984).

So many imbecilic directors and so-called writers out there.

How do these movies get approved? Desperation during Covid?

Basically nothing makes sense in this movie. The acting is terrible. Directing, writing and editing are terrible.

Characters are terrible. Plot is terrible. Climax is terrible.

Save your money and time. Don't watch this utter crap.

I really enjoyed this movie.

Watched it with my wife which she doesn't know anything about GI Joe and she enjoyed the action in it.

I, as a Joe fan, loved it from the personal angle of Snake Eyes, and especially the other characters that were included, and can't wait to see more Origins for others as well!
This movie has it all wrong. I'm disgusted with the movie and the producers who refused to follow the true back story of snake eyes. Heck get his nationality right. But nope.
Plot, acting and cinematography comes together to make one hot mess that would be better suited for the DVD bargain bin.

review_title: Abandon Ego. Don't Watch This Movie.
review_detailed_main: Wow, what a horrendous movie. I think this is quite possibly one of the worse movies I've seen in a while; it's not even so bad that it's good. Luckily I watched this on Netflix so I was able to skip parts; it was so bad I literally only watched maybe 30 minutes of it after all the skipping. I feel terribly for the people who actually paid good honest money to watch this tripe in the theatres.. The shallow and predictable story made zero sense, the actors were terrible - I've seen blocks of wood with more emotion and conviction, not to mention the dialogue was absolutely cringeworthy; it's as if the guy who writes fortune-cookie wisdom wrote the script. The action and fight scenes - which is the real reason why anybody would want to see this - were few and far between and when they did come, they were so random and really not anything we haven't seen before so basically just terrible. However, I do feel Iko Uwais was completely wasted, he basically had nothing to do, he barely got to use his martial arts skills. Other wasted actors include: Ursula Corbero who does amazing work outside of this movie, same with Samara Weaving. If this was supposed to be the origin story of Snake Eyes, it was also his ending; and why the hell did they change his backstory from the established canon? Were they trying to be clever or something? This POS of a movie made the Stephen Sommers G. I. Joe movies seem like works of art.

The script appears to have been written by someone who still plays with GI Joes. There no depth to any of the characters. The main character has no charisma and the plot is childish. Some of the initial action scenes were ok, but it get very confusing and low budget by the end. Camera shakes a LOT and cuts like crazy.

Why do we watch movies? I came into this movie without reading any review. I knew this movie was going to be good simply from the trailer. Snake Eyes has been a mystery in the GI Joe franchise, his past, etc. Why he took a vow of silence. We didn't know the answers to most of these questions from the current movies.

From start to finish, I was not disappointed with this movie. Each fight had careful and detailed choreography. The characters and acting were also great, so I'm not sure why people didn't like this movie? I'm not sure what they were expecting but the movie was exactly what I expected. Probably because I am a GI Joe fan so I already knew about the story a bit.

It was a great prequel. I would advise anyone to watch this movie with an open mind. Even if you don't know anything about GI Joe, I think this is a good movie.

review_title: Below Average, Predictable Twists, Gaping Logic Gaps
review_detailed_main: I watched this as part of my AMC Stubs membership so I can't complain about wanting my money back. I expected to be entertained and that I got but no better than a below average level. That was low for a big budget action thriller. The best thing I can say is, it's not terrible.

review_title: Worst movie ever. Not worth even a dollar in the flea market

review_detailed_main:
Henry Golding of Crazy Rich Asians and Monsoon takes the lead while Andrew Koji of Bruce Lee's Warrior is forced to be handled as Storm Shadow, the almost-brother-turned-venomous enemy in this modern day origin tale which doesn't really tell us much.

The scope of the relationship between Snake Eyes and Storm Shadow in the old series and movies implied a much deeper connection, yet here it seemingly spans all of about a week's time (okay, no dates were given but it begins and ends abruptly.) The connection between COBRA and Storm Shadow's past is really the only thing that seemed surprising, not to mention illogical given his final words to his family before 'storming' off.

All in all, Spiliotipolous and Schwentke's version doesn't stand up to the original and fails to find anything new to say.

All in all, Schwentke's version

All in all,

Released: July 23rd, 2021 Viewed: July 28th, 2021

Looking back over the last 12 years, since the first GI Joe film came out (GI Joe: The Rise of Cobra - 2009), the landscape, that this type of film inhabits, has changed some since then. In the years since 2009, a new type of film-franchising has taken the world by storm. Of course, I am talking about the cross-over franchise universes that are the Marvel Cinematic Universe and the DC Extended Universe. Both have managed to create self-contained film/TV universes, teaming with characters and worlds, full of stories to tell, for the next many decades to come. It even has helped earlier franchises, such as Star Trek and Star Wars, find/expand their franchise limits even further as well. Heck, even the Legendary Pictures Godzilla/Kong Monster-verse seems to be working also. Looking at this new form of film franchise creation, from a Hasbro production perspective, creates a certain problem for the success of this film.

When looking at Hasbro's success since the first Transformers (2007), came out, the money is definitely there, but the critical response has been a difficult road for the toy/entertainment giant. That is the part we want to concentrate on here and not the monetary value of the IPs. We should be honest here and say that Hasbro's best film was Battleship (2012), which never got a sequel and maybe, half of the Transformers movies were better than fair. We also should note that, the first two GI Joe movies were not really great either. Could Hasbro do something to correct the course that this seemingly damaged IP has? Can it learn a lesson from what came before it without being a modern day film cliché? What really is worse is, these are just the beginning of the hurtles that Snake Eyes: GI Joe Origins (2021), needs to face in order to be good.

Snake Eyes picks up on many film clichés, new and old, such as, the fact that it copied the X-Men Origins concept by making it GI Joe Origins. I saw some Guy Ritchie inspired text placements (see Wrath of Man - 2021), throughout this film. Many of the motorcycle scenes looked like they were pulled right out of Akira (1988). It even had the standard superhero lineup that happens right before the big climactic fight scene commences. There's even an after credits scene. In fact this totally looked like a carbon copy of a Marvel attempt. Also, don't release this film in a year that is already teeming with Asian-inspired, action-type, plot lines. We just saw the release of the Mortal Kombat (2021), remake. A new Kung Fu (2021), show just debuted on the CW. Plus, we have been gearing up for the last 18 months for the soon to be released Marvel film, Shang Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021). There is going to be content saturation that will effect originality.

The producers try to salvage the GI Joe film series by placing all its hopes on exploring the origin of one of its main characters. The problem stems from the fact that this type of character has been seen before and may not be as original an idea after all. They decide to pick a character, who is mostly a faceless, dark, shadowy, ninja type of persona. He is always seen that way in the GI Joe films, known for wearing a dark black hooded mask, who usually doesn't say much either. Now we have a backstory about this guy, which doesn't hold your attention much, because the character was so one dimensional already. We learn how he becomes Snake Eyes and what contributions the snakes play into his story, but that aspect starts to counteract the whole original form of the character. You begin not to care. It is a GI Joe story, but it becomes boring and dull. There are some good action scenes that seem hampered at times by the slow script. The excellently choreographed stunts begin to look all too familiar.

That by no means implies that this is a horrible film. Not by a long shot. There are some good points to this film. Some interesting aspects that make it compelling to watch. If you look at this film based on basic technical film principles then it is a perfect film. It has all the polish, professional perfections that any Hollywood film made today has, but after 125 years of movies, that isn't always enough. The film was way too long and when we finally get to the part of the movie centered around that pivotal moment when we finally learn the GI Joe connection with Snake Eyes, is fumbled. That great moment when these two huge pillars of the plotline first meet, becomes almost an afterthought.

What saves this film is the excellent acting by the superb, almost completely, Asian cast. One of the great aspects of Snake Eyes, who is from Asian-descent, named after a pair of dice, is completely American (since he was captured as a young child and grew up in Los Angeles), gets thrown into a situation in this film taking him all the way to Japan and he can only speak English. He is that real American hero, who needs his captors, allies and enemies to speak English to him or else those big speeches at the start of fights won't fall on deaf ears. So by casting a good, competent, professional group of Asian actors, who can articulate their lines well for the main character, as well as, for the audience, is done quite well in this film. The acting is top notch in this one. It brings in the non-perfect, human aspect of the equation, that makes Snake Eyes' character more interesting.

There also are many cool camera shots of Tokyo and other surrounding areas of Japan. I enjoyed some of the action scenes that did have an aura of familiarity to me. I am giving Snake Eyes an E+ for Effort and I still recommend seeing the film in theaters to support the excellent work of the Asian cast. GI Joe fans might like this exploration into their most famous and popular character, but for everyone else in the audience this film may feel too long, familiar and at times boring. I just hope GI Joe fans weren't as mad as I was when that pivotal moment, when Snake Eyes learns about the Joe Organization, ends up being less exciting then a yawn. The snakes were silly too, but nerve-wracking.

5.2 (E+ MyGrade) = 5 IMDB.

It was a awesome movie, just watch it. :) We finally get to see the storie about Snake Eyes.

I feel like this was one of those movies where 10 years down the road they're going to look back and go "wtf?" and remake it. Hopefully.

They really had a chance to tackle one of the coolest characters ever. A chance to explain why he is what he is, where he came from, how he feels, etc. Unfortunately, all of that lasts all of about 15 min of the film. review_title: Why do execs approve movies assuming it'll get a sequel?
review_detailed_main: I wanted to like this, Ninjas, Joe's and bad guys. Not much to dislike there right? Except the lead was an unlikable character with a terribly written script, Tommy was better, but each scene flipped between a buddy movie vibe to the tortured soul and sadly his accent slipped more often than that. The supporting cast also went back and forth, this is like the film had two directors, neither of whom knew the other one was also working on this film, and they each had a different brief.

review_title: They didn't do justice to my favorite Joe...
review_detailed_main: This movie might have been cooler if they incorporated Snake Eyes's vow of silence. Instead they made the character so arrogant and otherwise undeveloped that the character couldn't have become the one we know; pretty much the opposite of the point of an origin story. This movie actually made Storm Shadow the better character but his arc was still rushed almost as badly as Daenerys's was in Game of Thrones. I really wanted to like this one more than I did.

review_title: Great action and perfect for a G.I. Joe movie.
review_detailed_main:
I see what everyone else is saying in their reviews, but I have to disagree. This is actually one of the most appropriate marshall arts action films for the PG-13 audience this year! I found it refreshing NOT to see blood and guts every 5 seconds. No crazy gratuitous or inappropriate sex scenes thrown in? GREAT! This is G. I. Joe! It's not supposed to be a rated R film. This is for kids and grownups like myself that watched the old show in the 80s. If you're looking for something else, then move on.

My only gripe is the use of the F word. You have the entire movie going at 100% and then you drop a random unnecessary F bomb? That was just dumb. Otherwise a good movie that certainly would have made money if not for the pandemic...... and the f bomb. ✌🏾

review_title: Another bad attempt at starting a GI Joe movie franchise
review_detailed_main:
GI Joe was never my thing when I was growing up. My only experience with this IP was the two big blockbuster GI Joe movies and they were terrible. Snake Eye was the best aspect of those terrible movies though as he was a badass mute ninja. I was a little surprised and intrigued when it was announced that there would be a prequel/reboot focused on him before he was mute. The premise is "An ancient Japanese clan called the Arashikage welcomes tenacious loner Snake Eyes after he saves the life of their heir apparent. Upon arrival in Japan, the Arashikage teach him the ways of the ninja warrior while also providing him something he's been longing for: a home. However, when secrets from Snake Eyes' past are revealed, his honour and allegiance get tested -- even if that means losing the trust of those closest to him". So is the Snake Eye origin a story worth telling or is it just another bad attempt at the GI Joe franchise?

Firstly, Henry Golding is good as the titular character. It is clear that Henry is giving 100% in every scene. There is an emotional moment in the final act and Henry gives a very convincing performance during it. Andrew Koji is also great as Tomisaburo Arashikage/Storm Shadow. He has a really strong voice and presence that is great to watch. I also love the moments between Henry's Snake Eye and Andrew's Storm Shadow. The chemistry between the two is great and it does feel like they were close friends or brothers. I also really like the gorgeous set design from the Japanese style of the Arashikage base to the neon-filled city. There is also a pretty good action sequence with long takes in the rain at a neon-drenched alleyway that was visually good to watch.

Unfortunately, the rest of the action sequences in this film are forgettable. The director, Robert Schwentke, implements shaky cam during close-ups of fights and also uses a ton of quick cuts which ruins the scene. It's such a shame as the alleyway fight scene shows that he could easily do entertaining fights but doesn't. The music score is also very generic with this electronic thump sound throughout the movie that occurs in action and even non-action scenes.

The biggest issue with this movie has got to be the terrible screenplay and story. The titular character, Snake Eyes, is an unlikeable main character that is difficult to root for. Without spoiling things, he does questionable things for the sake of revenge for the death of his father. Additionally, his redemption arc happens right at the very end of the movie and by that point, I could not like his character anymore. He didn't deserve any forgiveness whatsoever. Furthermore, Tomisaburo becomes the famous GI Joe villain, Storm Shadow, through some stupid logic. The first two acts of the movie is a grounded ninja, martial art movie but the final act is a tonal shift with it feeling more in line with superhero movies with silly magical power garbage.

Overall, Snake Eyes: GI Joe origins is the best GI Joe movie so far but it is still a bad movie. This movie succeeds in ruining the titular character by turning him into a dumb idiot. It also has forgettable action sequences that feel more aligned with generic action movies than the famed martial art movies. I don't know if this will get a sequel or another reboot in 10 years but I hope the next entry is a lot better than this...
Worst Acting, Worst Action, Worst Dialogs and Worst Cinematography.

review_title: Mediocre, hugely generic action movie based on the hit 80's cartoon.
review_detailed_main:
This is the G. I. Joe origins story of Snake Eyes. I have never seen G. I. Joe while growing up and there have been other memorable cartoons like He-Man and Masters Of The Universe and the 80's Spider-man cartoons.

So I don't know a lot about the backstory of all these characters. As a newcomer watching this movie, the feeling of it is like a sci-fi ninja film at some times with elements of mythology and the supernatural. They have crossed many genres making this one.

The film is not that dull and will hold your attention but after starting to watch this one you will feel a compulsion to finish it and find out what happens at the end.

For me the farcical parts of the movie were just plain ridiculous and when it turned to the mythological from being a straight-up ninja film, I knew that the ending would be pointless, but I sat through till the very end.

For those who have watched that cartoon series in the '80s, no doubt you will be sorely disappointed. It is nothing like what you have been used to before. Still in a manner of speaking it is better than the Black Widow movie I have seen.

review_title: Don't be put off by all the negative reviews. Watch it and make up your own mind, you won't be disappointed!!

We sat and watched it as a family of 2 adults and 2 teens, 2 of which are not normally action fans but everyone enjoyed the film!
